editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE FOOL Would be a FAVOURIT: Or, the DISCREET LOVER. A Trage-Comedy.
LONDON, Printed for Humphrey Moſeley, and are to be ſold at his ſhop, at the Prince's Armes in St. Pauls Church-yard. 1657.

list.item: Agenor, His ſon, in love with Lucinda.
Adraſtus, A Lord, in love with Aurelia.
Young Gudgen, The Favourit that would be.

body.head: THE FOOL Would be a FAVOURITE: Or, the DISCREET LOUER.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: CAN the Prince Philanthus, my coſen, look ſo far beneath himſelf, as on my ſervant.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Madam, believe me, he makes love to her daily, and now they are together in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
If this be true, as I begin to fear, for I have heard him make ſome deſperate proteſtations; yet, by the ſtronger Magick of this brow, I'le break thoſe Spells that hold him; theſe Eyes, which have to all that ſued • een clad in frownes, ſhall, for his ſake, receive all the •• ditions, that a womans art can give, to make them • ictors. He ſhall not caſt away himſelfe, nor ſpend a
ſigh more, for ſo mean a perſon. For ſure, when I ſhall coſen him, making him think, that I will daigne to love, hee'l hate himſelfe, and flie ſo mean a Miſtreſſe. I'l ſee, if they be ſtill together.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I ſee the Princeſs comming.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: The better. Injure not ſo much your own merit,
To miſdoubt the truth of what I ſay; and if you fear
A change, I'le call the gods to witneſſe.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Good my young Lord, ſpare your raſh inconſiderate oaths,
Which you would be content to buy again at any rate,
Within this month.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Crafty Wench, ſhe ſees us.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You muſt not think, that I will lay my ſelfe
Open to your courtſhip thus alone, it was
By accident you met me, pray let go.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Will you then leave me?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: How now, Coſen, making love to Miranthe?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Madam, I ſhould be glad to gain her good opinion.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Conſen, I hope the Court has not infected you as yet. Will you diſſemble with me your friend, or no, if I ſhould ſeriouſly ask you a queſtion?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Madam, if I already know that vic •••… name,
My I or No, will be but ſmall aſſurance.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: yet I dare truſt you. Love you Miran earneſt?
Why do I ask? I do not think you yet know love means.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Not what it is, I would I did not.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I ſee you do, that ſigh approves it.
And, Miranthe, you love entirely.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Admit I grant.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Leave us a little. Then you muſt grant withall,
That you much injure your ſelf; for you are equall
To the greateſt in your blood; to ſay, your minde
Or perſon's lovly, is a truth, befits ſome other
Better then my ſelfe to ſpeak. Yet friendſhip,
And pitty of your youth, to ſee you ignorantly offer your devotions
To ſo poor a Saint, whoſe influence, though ne'r ſo favourable,
Cannot protect you from a generall ſcorn forces me
To tell you, you will be counted of a low ſpirit,
Or wondrous ignorant, in loving Miranthe,
Your birth being ſo far above hers.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Madam, 'tis true, that being deſcended from your houſe,
I ſhould have as juſt reaſon to be proud in that reſpect, as any:
But, being otherwiſe defective in thoſe things,
Which I could not receive from Anceſtours, my mind and manners;
Wonder not, that like a baſtard Eaglet, I refuſe to look upon
The Sun-bright Beauties of the Court. Yet, Madam,
You muſt think, in her I lord there's ſomething,
Though perhaps not obvious to your eyes,
That to me renders her lovely.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: 'Tis true, ſhee's a good Wench, perhaps her vertue takes you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Madam, I know you do not ſleight that in others,
••… ough in her you do; ſhee's your ſervant and you ſay,
••… e's my Miſtreſſe, and Vertue ſhould be Miſtreſſe to us all.
Give me leave ſo far, to juſtifie her and my ſelfe
as to ſay, If ſhe be more vertuous then the faireſt
Lady living, I ought to love her beſt.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Yes, if you could be married to her vertues, not to her perſon;
For fix pence I'le buy a Book, ſhall more inſtruct you in that way.
But think you, Coſen, Vertue and Beauty may not dwell together.
I am accounted fair, wherein have I appeared to you
Leſſe vertuous than Miranthe?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: In nothing, Madam, rather the wonder of your ſex.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Couſen, believe me, there are many in the Court, that exceed
Me in both. Let me perſwade you leave Miranthe rather
for your Man to woe, and dedicate your worthier ſervices
to ſome of thoſe that I ſhall name you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Madam, you perſwade ſtrongly, for I rely upon your counſell
As an Oracle But think you, I have handſomeſs o wit,
To make me acceptable to a fair Lady?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Yes doubtleſſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I fear you ſay it only, to draw me from my Miſtreſs.
But ſwear, you think me worthy.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: As I live I do.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well, Madam, you have perſwaded me to be unconſtant;
If there be a puniſhment, may't light on you:
Or, if I fail to gain a Miſtreſs, you muſt promiſe
To inſtruct me; for, whom you'l pleaſe to name
As worthy, I'le make love to tell you all my diſcourſe,
And ſhew you all my Letters.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l:
Muſt you needs be in Love, it ſeems you he
been much given to read love Books; when I know your ſtudy, I ſhall fit you with a Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Faith, Madam, they live ſuch pleaſant lives in thoſe books,
Kiſſing their Miſtreſſes hands, and looking on their fair eyes,
That I have envied them.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Your imagination's very ſtrong, you begin with me.
I muſt provide a Miſtreſs for you very ſhortly,
I ſhall be troubled with you elſe my ſelf.
Truſt to my skill thus far, I have wrought him handſomly
My part is onely, to be ready to entertain you.
No more
Fare-well then.
Fare-well. Let me alone to fit him here in the Country to the buſineſs, th'aſs is rich, his father more fool then he, doting upon his ſons believed perfections—Here comes the old fool.

sp.speaker: O. Gud.
sp.p: Good-morrow Mr. Courtier, you'r late a riſing; you ſhould have ſeen my ſon, your ſcholler, break halfe a doſen ſtaves elſe, as gratiouſly, as ere a poor mans ſon in Milain, and for Cut, black Cut.
Indeed hee's a good ſober beaſt.

sp.speaker: O. Gud.
sp.p: Very quick, he ſtarts before you can tell twenty; firſt does he trot, but then ſtand; I have the barrier thus with my whip aloſt, and when he comes, flaſh quoth I, away goes Cut ſo faſt, you cannot ſee him move, then does he ſtop moſt willingly.
He does indeed.

sp.speaker: O. Gudg.
sp.p: And turnes about with great 'liberation and 'gillity, but old Roane what ſay you to him, there a hot Jade indeed, as like my ſon as can be, firy and full of mettall, and here comes the grace of our Country, though I ſay 't.

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: Luckey, poulcroone, look to my Roa • Jennet, let him allay his fury in thy hand, before he fet his hoof within the ſtable, and ſhouldſt thou let him drinke, thou dieſt as I am generous.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Saving your young worships pleaſure; he had more need be ſet up, and have a peck of grains, heel ne're be able to plow to morrow elſe.

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: Peaſant, I ſay let him allay his heat, and for the plow thou talkeſt on, I will have thee know this mornings ſervice hath manumiz'd him from ſuch ba •• employments.

sp.speaker: O. Gudg.
sp.p: How Son, whats that?

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: I muſt ſpeak plaine to his dull underſtanding, oh torment! let it ſuffice that Roane is free from ſervice of the plow or harrow.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I your worſhip I am ſure hath harrow'd all the fleſh off his back, a little reſt and meat will do well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: Another word, and as I hope to be a Gentleman, Ile make him feed on thee.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Good your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: Nay worſe, thou ſhalt not wait upon m • to our Court of Milan.

sp.speaker: O. Gud.
sp.p: 'Tis his care, Son you muſt forgive him

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: Live then; and thank this aged Nobleman

sp.speaker: O. Gud.
sp.p: Oh hopefull boy, hee may be one indeed Sir may he not.
Yes yes?

sp.speaker: O. Gud.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter though I be a yeoman ſtill.
No no, there will be no great indecorum in it.

sp.speaker: O. Gud.
sp.p: I, as you ſay 'twere well I were a'the coram, and ſo I will when my ſon's a Lord.

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: How my cloaths not made yet! let me periſh, if I do not revenge the blood of all the innocent lice, ſince the firſt Taylor.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: I beſeech your worſhip, you know I wanted, and you promiſt to let me have ſome money before hand.

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: How Taylor! money before hand? doſt thou not know I am to be a Courtier, thou ignorant Country vermine, can there be hope to proſper in a ſuite paid thee for, before hand.
No tis unpoſſible you would appeare a prodigie

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: A prodigie; thats fine ifaith, nay I will pay aforehand then, and be a prodigie; if that be all my man to, he ſhall be a prodigie.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I thank your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: Maſter of the Dance and Fence you have been long a comming.

sp.speaker: Dancer.
sp.p: Your worſhip knowes tis two long mile and I came but ſoftly, I muſt be more carefull of my leggs then another man.

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: Why ſo man, thou makeſt new ones every day.

sp.speaker: Dance.
sp.p: I Sir but I make them with my leggs, and every trades man will preſerve his tools.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Or elſe his wife will Chide him when he comes home.

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, him ſol, ſol fa, fa.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: I am glad to hear your worſhip ſo carefull of my documents, uſe a voyce, and have a voyce.

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: Come come ſhall we to't?

Sir 'twere beſt to day you only us'd your martiall
exerciſes, you have rid, and fencing will be enough.

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: You ſay true, firſt I will learne to fight, and then to make my approaches to the Ladies: if they refuſe to yield to my Courtſhip,
Ile compell them by force of Armes.
How raviſh them, prove a Tarquine?

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: I, ten Tarquines, what ſhall they contend with me?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: By my faith, I will take your worſhips part.

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: Shee that ſhall oppoſe me had better come on Maſter of the Noble ſcience, behold thy ſcholler does thus confront thee.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Stay Sir you are too furious, firſt you muſt marke your diſtance.

sp.speaker: O. Gud.
sp.p: I but ſonne, you loſt your opportunity; I have ſeen the time I would not have fail'd to pai'd him o're the nodel, at ſuch a vantage.

sp.speaker: Y. Gudg.
sp.p: How take upon you to teach me, goe to, you'r an old buſie fool, but, lets ſee what you can doe, come on your waies.

sp.speaker: O. Gud,
sp.p: Alas ſonne, I am old, threeſcore.

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: I know you might have been my father, but I have ſeen a wiſer at thirty, come on Sir.

sp.speaker: O. Gud.
sp.p: Nay Son.

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: Take 'em, I charge you as you expect my favour, Ile let you ſee the fence is alter'd ſince your ſword and buckler time.

sp.speaker: Tav.
sp.p: I have an itching to him.
Sir your Father's old, you'l kill him.

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, I ſhall not be aſham'd o • him when I am a Lord.
Faith Sir, play with your Tayler, hee's a great mind too't.

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: Has he, come on Sir ſhred, dare you adventer, the third part of a man to encounter; doſt thou know what thou doſt, I am a prodigie.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: I Sir, but I muſt help to make you ſo: one bout ſir, and it were at Cudgels, I durſt venter the making of your worſhips cloaths.

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: Oh baſe Cudgels, I will kill that lowſe that ſits upon thy ninth button.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Well ſir.

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: Oh Rogue do you offer to ſtrike, and then to thruſt againſt the Order of fence, this 'tis to play with ignorance.
'Tis true ſir, I wonder you would doo't.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: I know the blow could not be great, alas I am but a louſe, a ſhred at the moſt, Sir, but the third part of a man.
Away, you are ſaucie.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Will pleaſe your worſhip to let me have ſomething before hand.

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: A pox on thee, thou haſt given me too much.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Truly ſir, it was againſt my will, I did not think it poſſible I could have hit your skilful worſhip, wilt pleaſe your worſhip try another bout?

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: No prithee.

sp.l: A pox a theſe Marſhall Exerciſes,
Lets to the City, Dance, Drinke, Whore, and Dice,
Theſe are the vertues, fighting is a vice.

sp.speaker: Adra.
sp.l: Oh inconſtant Aurelia, but women muſt be women ſtill,
Changing though for the worſt: for wherein can Philanthus be juſtly pris'd before me; hee's young
And unexperienc'd, ſo cannot ſerve her with that waryneſs
He ought conſidering her Birth, ſure ſhe cannot love him, oh yes ſhe does, ſhe does, it is apparent.
They are ſtill together and ſee, good manners pard me.
Ile marke their actions, tho I cannot heare.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Maddam do not refuſe to inſtruct me yo •• ſcholler.
But heare in what language I am able to deliver
My affection in, and give ſuch an anſwer as you think
Adraſtus ſiſter will do, whom you have
appointed me to make love to.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I will,

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Faire Aurclia.

sp.speaker: Aur,
sp.p: Her name's Lucinda.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Maddam you know that all one, but 〈◊〉 th'at-tribute of Faire ſufficient.

sp.speaker: A ••
sp.l:
Tis old and fooliſh either to ſay, faire or vertu •
〈◊〉
Or madam, miſtris, or goddeſſe, or Divine Lady
Sweete Creature, or abſtract, or indeede
Any thing that way.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Then thus, If the reſpect I beare your had bee • leſſe,
Or that after the tender of my loyall heart,
And your refuſall of it, I could have liv'd,
To enjoy your ſight I had long ere this
Made my love known, but ſince the
Manifeſtation of your diſdaine and my death are
Inſeparable accidents, wonder not that I
Have loſt ſo many opportunities to tell you.
For all Creatures have a deſire to preſerve life:
And now I ſee my laſt period approaching.
For in your heavenly eyes I read the ſentence of my death,
As plaine as if the book of fate lay open to me.
You'r are the book of fate in two reſpects,
To all that ſee and know you as I do.
For if they love you, they juſtly periſh by your ſcorne.
If they love you not, their ignorance tranſformes
Them into beaſts, a worſe Condition for a man
Then not to be at all hope cannot foole me further,
Then only make me to believe, that ſince
I have ſome intereſt in your blood youl ſhed a teare,
To witnes that you greeve my ruine.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: May I periſh, if you have not delivered this with as much paſſion.
As if Lucinda for whom this ſpeech was fram'd,
Had beene before you, but how ſhall ſhee conceave
That where you ſpeak of intereſt in her blood?
Are you akine to her?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: When you have anſwered in her perſon; for that, I ſhall reſolve You.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Well if your affection were thus violent as you pretend,
I cannot but acknowledge that the conſideration of it
Were ſufficient to move pitty in any woman,
That did allow the follies of proteſting lovers.
But for my part I have ever laugh'd at thoſe,
Who hop'd to gaine love by the manifeſtation
Of their ſufferings, and therefore had you profeſt leſſe
Till you had made your merits appeare greater,
It would have mov'd me more: when I ſhall ſee
That in you which I aſmuch covet to enjoy,
As it ſeemes you do now ſomething in me.
Then which an equality of affection we ſhall
Meet without all theſe ſophiſticated proteſtations,
And not before: for as you purſue that which you think
Would be your happineſſe; ſo do I mine.
Which I am ſure conſiſts in my freedome
From the follies of Love.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Tis even ſo, you have delivered nothing but what I expected.
The greateſt merit I ſhall ere attaine to,
Is quickly to remove out of the world.
One whom you ſomuch contemn.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Philanthus, would you take this way
To aſſure your miſtris of your affection?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: No other wayes then by my death after the aſſurance of her diſdaine.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: P'ſhew, you muſt not deſpair for the firſt deniall.
Our hearts and tongues do not alwayes agree.
And becauſe I am to inſtruct you to gaine your miſtris,
Ile diſcover ſome part of womens diſpoſition, to you;
Tho it be to our diſadvantage.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Maddam you ſhall infinitely oblige me.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Firſt there's few of us what ere we ſeeme,
But are content to be belov'd by all that ſee us.
And thoſe who are of birth may expreſſe love,
In their actions without offence, tho nere ſo many.
But he that comes to tell his miſtris in words he loves, her,
Had need be firſt aſſur'd that ſhee beleeves
That he hath worth enough to gaine a miſtris
Equall to her ſelf in merits, ſhould he make
Tender of his love elſe where: for when an other
Would receave that which is offer'd it does approve
The valew of the guift, and ſetts the giver
Free from ſcorne.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Maddam for this I thanke you, but more I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I will, it may be you beleeve you could not mor •
Oblige your miſtris to reſpect you then by giving
Her aſſurance of many oaths that you can never love
Any other Lady, tho ſhee ſhould much neglect you.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Maddam, I do.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I thought ſo, marke a generall errour: whatſoere,
We are ſure is ours, the worth of it doth leſſen
In opinion, for we are ſtill in purſuit
Of new and difficult things to attaine: yet it is
As great a greefe to us if our priſoners.
Should undo their chaines as 'tis contentment
To enthrall a new one and make another.
Womans ſervant ours, pleaſes above thought,
Becauſe it is a teſtimony of our great vertue
And merit that drew him.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: The Change may grow as well from his inconſtancy,
As Judgement in diſcerning the worthier.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: At leaſt he will add one to the number, and multiplying
Is the art moſt women ſtudy that are faire.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Are all ſo? Maddam; are you ſo?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I did not tel you I would give you my particular
Character, 'twas the generall I ſpake.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Maddam, I take it for granted, you are not ſuch.
For theſe you name, are faculty in their humours.
And therefore you being ſingular deſerve more love,
Which truſt me maddam I muſt pay to You.
Not to Lucinda what ere I have ſeem'd.
Nor ever lov'd I Miranthe.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: How Philanthus?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Maddam, tis true by all that can be ſworne by.
That I only love Aurelia now, but how long.
It will continew, if ſhee neglect me, that I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: This is fine Jugling, do you make me diſcover
The weaknes of our ſex, and then aſſault my ſelfe.
I hate you, hence from my ſight.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Maddam, I do not believe you, you told me your ſelf.
That womens hearts and tongues do not alwayes agree.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: But I told you withall I ſpoke not of my ſelfe.
And you granted too, I was not like other women.
Which you then made the argument of your love.
Therefore you muſt beleeve me when I ſay I hate you.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Yes when 'I do beleeve that, I deſerve it.
You ſwore you thought me worthy when you went about
To perſwade me from Miranthe, which aſſurance you
Said was neceſſarie before the verball proteſtation
Of affection, and feare not that you ſhall be too aſſur'd
That I eſteeme you, for I, according to your owne rule
Will ceaſe to love you when you uſe me ill.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Of which aſſure your ſelf, for you have offended me much.
I much above expreſſion, pray leave me to my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Maddam I will, but for my owne advantage.
For when I am gon, you cannot chooſe but conſider,
That my merit to your words is equall to the beſt.
Deſerver, henceforth I will not wo in words but action.
And if you love, each thought is of my faction.

sp.speaker: Adra.
sp.p: Bleſt opportunity.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: T'is well, this troubles me; yet ſure it cannot much diſpleaſe me.
For who in Philanthus can find the leaſt defect?
When I perſwaded him not to love Miranthe,
And thought it was a friendly care, I was deceav'd.
Sure then I lov'd, it could not grow thus in an inſtant.
How in an inſtant, do I love him then? no no.
I do not; yet it would trouble me to ſee him love another

sp.speaker: Adraſtus.
sp.p: I ſhall be troubled then.

sp.speaker: Adra.
sp.l: Maddam excuſe me that I interrupt your privacie
Forc'd by the violence of my paſſion, for when I ſhall be once.
Certaine of that which I ſtrongly ſuſpect,
There ſhall be nothing able to keep me
From ſudden death; not your command,

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Adraſtus, what iſt troubles you?

sp.speaker: Adra.
sp.p: Iſt poſſible that you can aske me?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You ſee I do.

sp.speaker: Adra.
sp.l: Maddam, you know how intirely I gave my ſelfe,
Reſerving no facultie of mind or body, to be imploy'd
Other wayes then by your Diſcretions, nor dare I ſay
I yet repent, tho I ſee another ready to reape
The fruit of my labors, 'tis Philanthus happy Philanthus
Whoe's the more fortunat in that hees not above me in merit,
In affection far beneath me, nor ſhould I greeve,
To ſee him happy, were he not raiſd upon my ruines.
But I muſt ſay to hope to ſee him one day forſaken
Like my ſelf: oh no I dare not, ſure this change proceeds
From ſome defect in me which you beleeve
You have found, and not from your inconſtancy.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Adraſtus, the knowledge which I have had of your actions towards me,
And my owne beauty, aſſur'd me that your lov'd.
But that my Courteſie had bred a beleefe in you,
That I deſired you ſhould do ſo, till now, I knew not of
Henceforward I ſhall ſet a remedy to that: For Philanthus
Being raiſ'd upon your ruins, tis a building of your fancy only.
But truſt me tis ſtrange you ſhould be Jelous of what your nere
Poſſeſt: but you beleeved you did, that was ſufficient.
From this time know to value me and your ſelf.
In ſo doing, you may regain that good opinion
I held of your judgment, which by this raſh •… you have loſt.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: Loſt, even ſo I am contemned, is this the ward
Of all my ſervices, all my fair hopes
Thus blaſted? This Philanthus was born to ruine 〈◊〉
In all attempts of war and peace, he robs me of prize,
What ere ſhe ſeemed, till Philanthus ſupplanted me
My ſervices were moſt acceptable.
I had not elſe forſook Miranthe for her, and well
I know, ſhee's even with me already,
Furthering Philanthus, my Rivall, in his affection.
Now I muſt look

For nought but ſcorns from Aurelia. Could I 〈◊〉
Philanthus
Yet with my ſelfe, 'twere ſome content; umh,
The way to do it, is, to continue the ſeeming friendſh •…
Which I bear him, ſo ſhall my plot be carried free
From ſuſpicion: Hee's of an open heart,
And ſuch natures are eaſie to work on.
The Politician, when he huggs, does ſtrike:
Rivalls in Love and State, will do alike.

div.head: Actus ſecundus.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: SIr, you have bound me to you by ſo many vours,
That you do give me cauſe to hope, that this
Diſcovery is not diſpleaſing to you.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Come, leave this ceremony, it does not fit our loves.
If you do love my ſiſter, the friendſhip I have vow'd,
Ties me to aid you, although I know it may much
Prejudice me in my Father's love, ſhould he know't;
For he ſo doats upon my ſiſter, that he believes
None but a god is worthy of her.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis true, ſhee's full of all that can be excellent
In women, yet ſo far do I prize you above mine own deſires or hopes,
That could your ſiſter recompence me with a love equall to mine,
And yet that love, purchaſt by you, prove prejudiciall to you
I rather would give o're the thought of love for ever,
At leaſt in ſilence rather pine and die.
No, far bee't from my friendſhip, to build my happineſs,
Though ne're ſo great, upon your ſmalleſt diſcontent.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: You wrong my love in this, and undervalue me;
For, you do ſeem to ſay, I fear to hazzard my fathers frown,
Though I could purchaſe for you what you ſo deſire:
Now, by the gods, 'twas a moſt unkinde thought;
Nay, from a man leſſe honeſt, 'twould appear
Hypocriſie; or, do you think my youth hath not yet taught me,
What 'tis to be a friend? Know, Philanthus,
The few years I have paſt, have been employed,
To make me ſomething capable of thoſe parts,
Which moſt enobles us; and I have found
Friendſhip to be the ſoul and eſſence of a man.
Therefore, believe me, ſince for your merits I have choſe you
For a friend, your diſcontents, dangers, and happineſs,
Are all mine; no, friend, I ſay, your growing love
Can plead for you, not without ſucceſſe.
She loves, but would not have you too aſſured on't,
Leſt it ſhould make you leſſe eſteem the purchaſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir, you, in this aſſurance of your friendſhip,
And her love, tranſport me with a double joy,
Not to be expreſt in words. I ſhould fall down,
And worſhip ſuch a god-like friend, that thus
Beſtowes his favours on a deſertleſſe perſon,
Made onely worthy by his love.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Still you forget our friendſhip, heaping your thanks
And praiſe on me, a burthen my weak deſerving
Cannot bear without much ſhame; let it ſuffice,
My love makes me a ſervant to your wiſhes;
If they do take effect, 'tis your own merits,
Whom the gods cannot refuſe, that's the cauſe of it.
My friendſhip onely a willing inſtrument,
Strives to bring their divine wills to paſſe.
But Oh! friend.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why ſigh you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I have long lik'd, and now I fear I love,
And therefore think, friendſhip obliges me
To tell you, yet with the reſervation of her name:
For ſhee's ſo cruell, ſo proud, if't be no ſacriledge
In me a Lover, to give that attribute.
I ſay, ſhee's ſo diſdainfull, and there's ſo little hope,
Nay rather ſuch a certain impoſſibility,
That ſhe will never love me, that I am aſham'd
To name the Tiger, that will in time, I know,
Conſume my heart.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Tell me her name, and ſend me to her, and I ſhall quickly
Make her know, ſhee's cruell to her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Oh friend, I do not wiſh to loſe you,
'Twere the ready way to make you falſe; ſuch a faith as yours
Perhaps, for once, might bring you off, free and untouch'd;
But ſhould you often ſee her, and converſe, you'd ſoon
Break faith with me and all the world, to gain
One ſmile from her; yet, even that ſmile were death,
Except you might enjoy them often: the deprivation
Of a good poſſeſt, being our greateſt miſery.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir, may I not know this wonder, for ſuch I muſt believe her,
From your love; but more, that you believe ſhe could
Taint my faith. Venture to name her.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: If you urge it as a duty, belonging to our friendſhip,
I muſt tell you; otherwaies I would for ſome
Reſpects conceal it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Except you mean to imploy me to ſerve you,
'Twill be to no advantage.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: If you will, I'le tell you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Faith, Sir, I ſhall not take it ill, if you conceal her;
May be, 'tis her will, becauſe her cruell uſage
Of you, if known, would be thought folly.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: 'Tis her will indeed; yet, friend, ſhe hath more wit then all her ſex.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir, were I not a Lover too, I ſhould believe you.

sp.speaker: Age,
sp.l: I dare not let you ſee her, ſo to approve it;
Shee'l quickly finde your worth to exceed mine.
Now is my friendſhip from leaſt taint moſt free:
If ſhe knew both, there might grow jealouſie.

div.stage: Enter old Gudgen, young Gudgen, 1. Courtier, and Man.

sp.speaker: Y. Gud.
sp.p: Paſſe not beyond this ſcore, I charge thee, Father, upon thy allegiance; we are now within the verge of the Court. Away, make haſte, to turn thoſe durty acres into crowns, to buy the place you wote of.

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: Well ſon, e'en god be with thee.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Weep not, I ſay, but get you home, and remember my bleſſing to the old woman, your wife; bid her not be proud of me, though ſhe have reaſon: Many a ſweet-fac'd youth, like my ſelfe, hath miſcarried at Court, comming to be a Favourite; but I'le buy't, and make ſure work, I.

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: Well, well.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: What, not gone yet, I think I ſhall be troubled with you. Sure I was a baſtard, I could not be his ſon, hee's ſuch a coxcomb.
Like enough.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: There have been Courtiers in our town, I and my mother was worth the whiſtling after, I can tell yee
I doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: But come, how do you like me?
Believe me, Sir, yee'r wondrous well accountred.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Well accoutred, is that a courtly phraſe?
Yes.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: I have heard ſome word neer it in the Country. And how do you like my vaſſail?
Very proper.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Is he not well accoutred? What's he, what's he, Sir?
Some poor ſleight fellow, you muſt be ſurly to ſuch, and look big.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.l: Nay, Sir, I can look big, I learnt that of my father's Bull,
He comes towards me.

sp.speaker: R. C.
sp.p: Noble Sir, I ſhall be wondrous proud of your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Then you ſhall never have it.

sp.speaker: R. C.
sp.p: Why, Sir?

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Pride is a deadly vertue, humility a ſin, that will better become your clothes. Look I not big? Ha! ſtay, what's he, what's he.
Some great man, by thoſe that ſue to him: you muſt abaſe your garb, and with an obſequious look ſalute him.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Sir, I profeſſe my ſelf the vaſſail to your Dog; if you keep none, I am a moſt devout and obſequious ſervant to your Cat.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I ſhall deſire to have the providing of her Mice.
Sir, I am full of employments, excuſe me, I muſt ſuddenly give his Grace an account.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: A great man certainly, 'tis well if I can come to ſpeak with him this two hours.
Sir, may I intreat to know, what place you hold in Court? this Gentleman, I can aſſure you, is worthy your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: No, no, Sir; alas, I'm an ignorant, and know nothing, wondrous ſimple, believe it; a week hence will be fair, I'le wait your leaſure. But what's your place, Sir, I beſeech you honour me, Sir.
Pray, Sir, ſatisfie him.
Sir, I'me a favourite to his Grace.
What luck have you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: I, is't not good luck? Why, Sir, I come to buy a Favourites place, and think I am as fit for't as another man, and will give as much mony too.
Believe it, Sir, you muſt pay well for't, 'tis a place of great advantage.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: I know't, Sir, but one may ha't for mony, I am aſsur'd on't.
Yes, you ſhall have mine on good conditions.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Good or ill conditions, I care not, that's all one, I'l ha't.
Sir, you know not yet the duties, nor the priviledges of the place.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: That's true, pray what are they?
Firſt, you may be alwaies next the Duke, and ſo advance, or elſe keep back ſuites, as you favour or diſlike the perſon.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Nay, I'le diſlike all ſuites, that are not like mine own.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: or mine.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: I, or thine.
The great men will give thee the firſt good-morrow, perhaps ſhew more reſpect, they are very courteous in this age: The Ladies, thei'I obſerve yee too, it may be, more then their husbands.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: That's brave ifaith.
Sir, hark yee, you muſt not ſeem ſo deſirous of it. Let me alone to talk with him, and make the bargain; let's go to the next Tavern.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Sir, I do not greatly care for this Favourites place of yours, I hear, a man ſhall never live in peace, my eares will alwaies be glowing; they'I do nothing but talk of me, and they'I be hang'd before they ſpeak any good.
Though you deſerve ne're ſo much. Come, let's go.
Nay, that's certain, they'I miſinterpret every action, if it proſper not; their faith in that is like to Turks.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Sir, I would have you know, I care not ijd. for your place; but if you'I go to the next Tavern, he ſhall agree with you for it.
Fie, Sir, you'I ſpoyle all.
But is there nothing the Duke may except againſt, in your friend?

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Except againſt me? 'tis impoſſible, he ne're ſaw me in's life: why ſhould he except againſt me then, am not I as fit for a favourite, as another man?
'Tis but a needfull objection.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Except againſt me?
Pacifie your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: I tell you Sir, if he ſhould but think of excepting againſt me, I would return into the Country preſently, as wiſe as I came.
Nay, good Sir, 'tis impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: And he were ten Dukes, I'de ſend him to ſeek a Favourit, I warrant you. Except againſt me? what me?
Nay, Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.l: I tell you, Sir, ſhould the Duke uſe me ſo,
His Dukeſhip does not a right Gudgen know.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Believe me, noble Philanthus, there's nothing
That in the paſſages of life hath more contented me,
Then the happineſſe of your friendſhip. The advantages of which,
You have now had, at this and all other exerciſes,
In the perſon of any other, would have given me cauſe
Of griefe and envy; but ſince 'twas my beloved
Philanthus, that rob'd me of the glory,
The theft was ſo far from diſpleaſing,
That with the priſe you won my heart too.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your friendſhip, Sir, does make you attribute
To merit, that which was due unto my fortune only,
Or rather to your policy, who by permitting
Me to win this prize, thinks to encourage me
Againſt ſome others, weaker then your ſelfe;
And when I am growen ſomething rich, by little victories o're them,
You'I ſhew, you onely let me grow to this,
That with more eaſe at once, you might increaſe your ſtore.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: In this you overcome me too, but ſure in love
You cannot; I think, were I ſtill certain to enjoy
Your friendſhip, I nere ſhould think of marriage:
For to ſay true, how can there be, in vain
Phantaſtick women, halfe that contentment found,
That's in a perfect friend.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis certain, in vain Phantaſtick women, there no content.
But, Sir, excuſe me, if I ſay, y'are in an errour,
If you hold all women ſo.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: This moves him, I'le try him farther. Are you infected with that errour,
To think, there can be any other good in women,
Than onely, that they do increaſe mankinde?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Certainly they'r good for ſomething elſe.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Yes, to ſet debate 'twixt the deareſt friends,
To ruine husbands in their ſtates and honours,
Nay, Kingdomes, Empires; in a word, for certain,
As they bring men into the world, ſo certain
Do they ruine all our joyes.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You ſpeak from malice, friend, I fear, not from judgment;
For you muſt give your opinion the lie, when you conſider,
That our Prince that governs us had a mother,
Who, whilſt ſhe lived, did govern him.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: It works. She was a Queen ordained by heaven and ſo
Indeed, that ſhe partaks none of her ſexe's
Ill, nor weakneſſes. Name another.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Shee's eaſily ſeen, did not your malice blind you;
The Princeſſe Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: As ſhee's a part of her divine Mother, I grant her excellent;
But that laid by, ſhee's but a woman.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: But a woman, would you have her a monſter, would yee?

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: I muſt cloſe with him, I am ſatisfied.
How his blood ſtirs at naming her.
Sir, I'le admit thoſe two to have ſome worth.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You had a mother Sir, and you have now a ſiſter,
Moſt perfect as I hear; will you bar them
From all that's worthy?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The Duke calls for you, he thinks your Lordſhips well
On your journey by this time.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Pray let him know no other.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: Dear friend, your pardon.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I do not like this carriage of Adraſtus,
He makes a greater ſhew of love to me
Then uſuall, pretending a ſtrange hatred
Againſt the nobler ſex of women; noble, becauſe
Deareſt Aurelia's one. How bleſt am I,
Though I dare onely whiſper to my ſelfe, I am beloved by her.
My plot was proſperous, & ſhee one of my beſt aſſiſtants,
To whoſe dear care I owe my happineſſe,
For by thy means, I did receive the firſt hope,
That I was beloved above what ſhe made ſhew of.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: And from me you muſt receive aſſurance of the contrary.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Ha! that Aurelia loves me not.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Shee's ſo far from loving you now, that ſhe Doth hate her ſelfe, that e're ſhe did

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oh! I am wretched, from what a pitch of happineſſe
Thou haſt thrown me in an inſtant, 'twas unkindly done; yet,
So ſoon to let me ſee thou haſt abuſed me
By thy flatteries, in this thou haſt diſturbed,
More then inform'd my judgment.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For, what care I for knowledge of that truth,
That brings a certain ruine?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: She did love you, and may again; croſſes in love are ordinary.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Shee'l hear me ſpeak, that I may know the cauſe,
At leaſt, of her diſpleaſure.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I know ſhe will not, her heart's ſo ſwoln with ſome offences.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I have no other comfort left me but my innocence
Each accident doth croſſe me. Tomorrow I muſt
Leave the Court, to wait upon the Prince;
How ſhall I get an opportunity to ſpeak to her,
The loſſe of time will ruine me, I muſt
By Letters make her know my innocence.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: When you are gone, if I can learn the cauſe
Of her diſpleaſure, l'le write.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Thou art all my comfort.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: See, Linda, what I found too in my Cabinet,
Looking indeed for one of my dear brother,
Kinde Adraſtus Letters.

sp.speaker: Lind.
sp.l: Believe me, Madam, the language of this Letter,
Conſidering the ſweetneſſe of the youth that ſent it,
Would have moved pitty, if not procured love,
From any other, but your cruell ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Alas, good wench, I ſee thou haſt a tender heart;
In truth I would it had been writ to thee.

sp.speaker: Lind.
sp.p: Well, Madam, you think none worthy but your brother Adraſtus.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I do indeed believe ſo; who equalls him in worth?
And till I finde one ſomething neer him, I ſhall not
Think of Marriage, I aſſure thee; for, my beauty,
Which gives place to none, will not permit me
To accept a ſervant, that is not equall to the beſt deſerver.

sp.speaker: Lind.
sp.l: Madam, though naturall affection ſtop your ears,
Againſt all reports, that do not ſound Adraſtus praiſe;
Yet, I by others hear, Philanthus and the young Prince,
In all reſpects far prais'd above him.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: Why, Madam, ſpeak you with ſo much ſcorn, hee's now
Accounted the glory of the Court, a man fram'd
Both for Love and Armes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Piſh.

sp.speaker: Lind.
sp.p: You never ſaw him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nor nere deſire.

sp.speaker: Lind.
sp.l: Well, Madam, you are ſtrangely averſe, take heed
Love do not lay ſome puniſhment upon you,
Equall to your contempt of his great deity.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Contempt of his great deity, had he a temple
Standing near, dedicated to him, and to his
Mother both, I would go in and yerk his little worſhip:
Or ſhould ſhe ſay, I were not fairer then her ſelfe,
And more to be adored, I'de break her Statue,
And thoſe, whom by my beauty are captive made,
Should in th'ſtead of it, erect my Picture, frowning too,
That any ſhould preſume to love me; yet in thoſe
Clouds, more powerfull to draw mens hearts to my devotion,
Then ſhe, with all her wanton blandiſhments.

div.stage: Enter Duke, Adraſtus, Aurelia, Courtiers, and Servant.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Daughter, me thinks you'r ſad, is't for your
Brothers abſence,—hee's now upon return.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I am not ſad, Sir, 'tis but your conjecture.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Adraſtus, are there no ſports, no pleaſures to delight her?

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: None, Sir, the Court is clouded in the abſenc • of the Prince.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: What means this Trumpet? one go ſee.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: A ſtranger Knight, Sir, one that deſires to be admitted to your preſence.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Wee'l hear what he demands: What would yee?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Great Duke, know, that this Knight is hither come,
To repair himſelfe by Armes, of an injury
He hath received; nor can he fear, ſo juſt a Prince
As your ſelfe, will break an honourable cuſtom,
That hath been ſo long us'd amongſt your Anceſtours.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: It cannot, nor it ſhall not be refus'd.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Is Adraſtus in this company?

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: Yes, I am the man.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Then, Sir, my Maſter will maintain with his life,
That you have belyed a Knight, equall to your ſelfe
In merit, in whoſe behalfe hee's come to prove,
That you have wickedly invented that,
Which you have ſaid of him.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Though I do not know your Maſter, which might excuſe
A man of my birth; yet, confident in mine owne innocence,
As having wronged no man, I do accept the Combat.
Get me my Armour, nor ſhall it longer be deferr'd,
There cannot be more noble witneſſe.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Adraſtus, I priſe you too much, to ſuffer it.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: How, Sir? then may my arms rot off, if ever I
Lift them in your ſervice; and yet my heart
Miſgives me in this occaſion, more
Then ever. Puſh is't not before divineſt,
Aurelia? I ſhall do wonders.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: What can this ſtranger be? or what can
Be the wrong, he now ſeekes right of from Adraſtus,
Whoſe valour makes him famous through the world?

div.stage: Enter young Gudgen and his man.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Save your refulgent grace.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: How now, who are you?

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: A poor favourit of you graces, that deſires to be better acquainted.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: A favourit of mine, how came you ſo?

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Knowing my ſelfe fitly qualified, and well accoutred, as they ſay, I made bold to venture a ſumme of mony.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Is this he?
Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: I am bound to you, it ſeemes you love me well, that would buy my ſervice, venturing in it my refuſall of yee too.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Yes, in good faith, I love yee very well; I have heard in the Country a good report of you; beſides, y'are bound to love me too, by my place.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Who ſwore you, your own imagination?

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Swore me, why, do you miſdoubt me? I warrant yee, Sir, I'l execute it rarely.—Stand by there, the Duke is buſie, another time hee'l hear you.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: We ſhall be troubled with this Aſſe.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Take away this fellow, you hear what the Duke ſaies,

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Take him away, this is not a time for fooling, I am ſerious.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Your grace is wiſe, 'tis true indeed. See the Councill-Chamber made ready, 'tis a buſineſſe of great importance, worthy your fear. I would my old father were here, we two would adviſe you rarely i faith.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: A way, coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: He has a villanous head of his own, hee'l tell you how many acres of land are in your Dukedome, and never meaſure it.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Another ſhall meaſure it for him.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Away with this fool.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Slight! what do you uſe a young Gentleman and a favourite thus, that comes out of his meer love to Court?
Hee's quite diſcouraged, that rude fellow hath ſpoil'd all.
Not a whit, if I do not raiſe him to a beliefe above what he had, ne're truſt my skill.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: 'Twas you Sir, that made me believe, I ſhould riſe at Court.
Why, ſo you do; but you are no ordinary Favourite, they riſe firſt, and fall after commonly; but you ſhall riſe after your fall.
'Tis not without example.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Are the Knights ready?
Yes, Sir, ſee where they enter.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Then let the juſtice of the injured's cauſe protect them
Was ever ſeen a braver Combat?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: 'Twere pitty to loſe ſuch Knights, perhaps their quarrell,
Truly underſtood, may not be great.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: The ſtranger does appear the braver.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: I fear Adraſtus. Sweet daughter, make tryall of your power,
To ſtay the Combat, 'tis an an office will become you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Moſt willingly. Sir, I beſeech you hold.
sp.stage: She pulls him, and he turning ſuddenly, her fear makes her fall; he offering to help her, Adraſtus comes behind; but he recovering himſelf, laies Adraſtus at his feet.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Traitor, this baſeneſſe will expreſſe thee.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Hold, Sir, I adjure you by her whom you
Beſt love, give me his life.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Let him confeſſe the wrong he has baſely
Done to me, and her whom you adjure me
By; and he ſhall live by your command,
Though far unworthy to be ſo obliged.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: I am dead elſe, I do, or any thing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Live then, to be more miſerable then death could make thee.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Be carefull of Adraſtus, but ſee this ſtranger
Receive no injury, from any of Adraſtus friends.
Though ye have fought with one that we love dearly,
Yet, I ſo much admire your courteſie
And valour, that I ſhould think my Court
Much honoured by your ſtay.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Friends, if you love me or my fortunes, revenge me,
The way I leave to your diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Friends.
sp.l: Enough, wee'l die or doot',
Notwithſtanding the Dukes command.

div.head: Actus tertius.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: LIghted that arm'd Knight that rid faſt by, at that little houſe?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: Hee did Maddam, this fine day hath tempt you
To walke further then you think: they ſay there's often
Robberies done in this wood.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Alas poore wench art afraid.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What are theſe that make this haſte.
Oh Maddam, theeves I feare.

sp.p: Saw you a Knight ride by here, dear Lady iſt you

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Well met ſir, yes I ſaw him, how does my brother?
Oh ſpeak, I long to know, I dreamt of him to night.

sp.p: Maddam I fear your brother is no more.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ha? dead? Oh ſpeak it not, for I ſhall bear him companie.

sp.l: Rather ſhew us which way that Knight went, the Author of his death.
That ſo we may revenge his murther.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Oh heavens, murder'd? yet you are juſt ye powers
That makes me thus the inſtrument of his revenge.
I will not waſh this hand kercher in womaniſh teares,
But firſt in the murderers blood, then clenſe it againe
With tears for my dear Brother.

sp.p: But Maddam, which way went he?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ile bring you where you cannot miſſe him, tis
Not long ſince I ſaw him enter a little houſe.
As we came walking hither.

div.stage: Enter an old man, and an old woman.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Now his wounds are dreſt, hee ſleeps ſoundly.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Alas good gentleman, he takes our poore entertainment kindly.
He ſaid at firſt he would come hither when he went to fight.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: I wonder his man that dreſt him, ſtaies ſo long.
'Tis not far to the next Town.

sp.speaker: O Man.
sp.p: What are theſe? theeves?
Stop their mouths, he ſleeps, ſhal I ſtrike him dead?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No let me ſee the Murderer firſt, ſure he looks ugly.
You need not kill him, let the law ſeiſe on him.
Maddam I would not have him wake, hee's ſtout.
'Twil not be in our powers to compell him.
By all the gods, 'tis Philanthus, but he ſhall die.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Stay—it muſt be by my hand, no other.
I am moſt injur'd, and ſo moſt intereſted in the revenge.

sp.p: Alas you are not able.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Leave it to me, or elſe by all that's ſacred:
Ile lay you open to the Law give me your Dagger:
Retire and leave me.

sp.p: Alas Maddam you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Are you ſuch fooles, not to be content
To have a dangerous enterpriſe effected, and your ſelves
Freed from danger of the Law, none will ſupect me.

sp.p: Maddam, if he ſhould wake.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Stay you without, and if you hear me call
For help: come in, not, otherwiſe.
We dare not diſobey you, her own great ſpirit
And the much love ſhe beares her brother, makes her,
Forget her ſex.

sp.p: But we ſhall loſe your thanks, ſince ſhe performs it.

sp.l: Not a whit, he ſhall not know it for us, how ere
Shee's a witneſs of our zeal to doo't; and we are free
From danger of the Law, if ever the deed be known.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis done, away, he welters in his blood, leave all to me.
But what for theſe?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Fie, no, 'tis unneceſſary, by giving Gold,
Ile make them ſpeechleſs ever, but now I better
Think, beare them into ſome wood and bind them
But hurt them not.
Maddam, 'tis poſſible, your brother may not yet b • dead.
How ere this act will pleaſe him much.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Not dead? this may be malice, then if it be known,
I'le Juſtifie the Act, if not the thanks and recompence
Be you from him. Ile ſend, and know the truth of all.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: Oh Maddam I never thought you could have done a wickedneſſe like this.
The wounds which you have given will ſtrike
Your own ſoul deep one day.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: Oh fool the wounds I have received are far more dangerous,
Then thoſe that I have given.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Maddam your own hand's cutt.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: 'Tis ſo, all the blood thou ſeeſt came only from thence.
Let me with better leaſure looke on what I have preſerv'd.
His travell makes him ſleep ſound.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: Madam, how bleſt were you to change your cruel reſolution.
Some Angell prompted you to ſave him from thoſe
Murderers, by ſeeming, as if you did your ſelfe intend to be one.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: There was no other way; but the good angell
That prompted me, was Love; 'twas ſtrange I ſhould
Be taken by a ſleeping man, that have from all eyes
That have ſeen me, almoſt baniſhed ſleep,
To think upon my beauty, which muſt be now
My part for him; for, I have loſt my ſelfe
By ſaving him, ſince I am ſiſter to his enemy.
Yet, he may love like me, when he intends revenge:
But ſhall I be ſo lovely when I ſleep, and he behold
Some ſtand ready to murder me, ſo making
Pitty uſher love into his heart, as into mine?
For all waies elſe have been before attempted
To make me amorous, none prevailed: Oh no,
It cannot be, he ſtirrs, away.
I muſt do ſomething,
What, I cannot tell:
Who loves, and dares not ſay, he lives in hell.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Miranthe, have you known valour, and ſo little courteſie,
meet in the perſon of one man ſo fully,
As in this Knight that overcame Adraſtus?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Madam, his valour did appear to all,
But wherein he behaved himſelfe diſcourteouſly,
I am yet to learn.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: What Knight but he, would have refuſed to ſtay
Their Combat, when I, a Princeſſe,
Not to be contemn'd, beſought him?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Oh, Madam, how unjuſt you are, ſince you accuſe him
In that, wherein you ought to thank him?
You ſaw, when through your fear you fell, he turn'd
To take you up, by which he did receive
A wound, I feat too mortall, by that moſt baſe
Adraſtus; and if he had given o're the Combat
Afterward, when you deſired, his enterpriſe
Had been moſt vain from the beginning:
Adraſtus had not then confeſt, that you or any
Might have heard, the lies he had invented.
But Philanthus is moſt unfortunate, to have
His beſt deſervings ſtill miſinterpreted.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: How! was't Philanthus that fought? me thought indeed,
The voice was his▪ but he being thought ſo far off,
Kept me from being certain.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: It ſcap'd my tongue before I was aware,
Now I muſt make it good. Yes, Madam, it was Philanthus,
To whom I did give notice in a Letter,
How much Adraſtus injured you and him,
By ſaying, Philanthus boaſted of the great love
You bare him, in every place, and that you partly did
Believe, he ſpake but truth, which was the cauſe
Of your diſpleaſure.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Is't then Philanthus hath done me this diſpleaſure?
Durſt he put my honour on the hazzard of fortune?
Durſt he capitulate and make conditions,
When I did beg Adraſtus life? am I ſo miſerable,
That I was gladder to receive, then he to give
What I did ask?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Oh poor Philanthus, how happy art thou, if the wound
Thou didſt receave, helping her up, have freed
Thee from thoſe greater torments, which her cruelty
Prepares, in recompence of all thy faithfull ſervices.
But, Madam when I think on't, did not you ſay,
He was to right himſelfe with his ſword, if he knew
No other remedy; and with more ſecrecy, or more
Diſcretion, it was to bar the action, all
Thinking Philanthus to be far hence,
Even when he drew their eyes to wonder at his valour.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Peace, no more of him, you praiſe him without cauſe.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Without cauſe?
When as his death, caus'd by your cruelty,
More then his wounds, ſhall make the world know,
'Twas he that overcame Adraſtus, and for your ſake,
As well as for his own. How will the vertuous
People tax you, of your great injuſtice?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe, I ſhould be very ſorry his death
Should give the world a knowledge of my follies.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Be not you cruell to him, and prevent it.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Nay, let him love himſelf, and ſave me a labour.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Madam, he cannot love that, which he thinks you hate.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Hee's neither worthy of my hate nor love.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Madam, 'tis impoſſible there ſhould be that indifferency
Towards Philanthes, whom you muſt either love,
Or hate extreamly.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Well then, I do not hate him, my brother; upon your life
Let him not know, that I do know the ſtranger was
Philanthus. Miranthe, ſeek not to excuſe him, hee's a moſt
Diſcourteous Knight, and I do hate him deadly.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Who's that ſhee ſpeaks of?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: The ſtranger-Knight.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Believe me, fiſter, you had no reaſon.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I know mine own reaſons beſt.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: But, ſiſter, when you hear mine, which are ſtronger,
You'l be of another minde.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You may as ſoon perſwade the fixed Starrs
To move, as me from my opinion. 'Twas ſure
Some inchantment that overcame Adraſtus.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Then you'l abandon reaſon quite, this truely ſhowes,
You women think your foes your friends, your friends your foes.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Villains, for what reſpect is't, that you do preſerve
Me longer, to torment me? why did you not rather
Kill me, when you found me ſleeping firſt?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: 'Twas not in our commiſſion, you are reſerved to feel
A thouſand torments, to which death is a pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: From what perſon living have I deſerved ſuch uſage?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I'le let you know your miſery, the more to torment you.
Know, that we are ſervants to a Lady, the moſt malitious
And deformed, that ever lived; ſo great
An enemy to vertue, that 'tis her onely ſtudy
To deſtroy thoſe men in whom it doth inhabit.
Her vigilancy for miſchiefe is ever buſie.
It ſeemes ſhe hath found you out to wreak her ſpight upon,
Intending here to keep you ever, except ſhe ſhall
Prove mercifull, and kill you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: If her hate to me onely proceed from a beliefe,
That I am vertuous, it ſeems ſhe knowes me not,
I am not ſuch. But if thou beeſt a gentle villain,
Tell me, where I am.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Far from the houſe, in which we found you ſleeding,
And now in the moſt loathed Priſon, that ever eyes
Beheld, if eyes can be of uſe in ſo much darkneſſe;
Your chiefeſt companions muſt be Toads, Snakes,
And Froggs, except two villains ſometimes, as now, ready ſtand,
To inflict torments, that cannot be expreſt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oh that I could but ſee, and were unloos'd, that with my fiſt
I might reward thee for this kinde relation.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Screech Owles and Ravens, ſhall fill thy ears continually
With diſmall ſounds. Hark.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sure ſome power, pittying the miſery that I muſt ſuffer,
Gives me this farewell to all happineſſe.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Now begins your torments, but that they may be more
Senſible, let him ſee him his miſery.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Amazment ſeizes me, is this a loathed Priſon?
Or this the harſh and diſmall notes of wicked birds?
Or look theſe men as they would ſtab, rather adore me.
What do I fool my ſelfe, this is a dream.
I am ſure aſleep.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Propoſe your wiſhes, and we are ready to effect them,
As far as lies in human power.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This is no dream, I am awake, this is my hand,
And theſe my hairs, I feel pain, now I pull them.
Sure 'tis a viſion, or worſe inchantment; the wicked Miſtreſſe
Of this houſe, to all her other ills, is certainly a witch.
I am confirmed 'tis ſo, for here ſhe comes,
Changed in a form equall to Aurelia, and far more
Gently does ſhe look upon me, than ſhe did at our parting.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sir, you are welcome, if there be defect in any thing,
It comes from negligence of ſervants, not from my will.
A valiant Knight, and flie thus from a Lady!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What ſhould I fear, ſhe cannot hurt my mind
With all her art, how ere ſhe may my perſon.
Beſides, ſhee'l change her form, and look before ſhe do me ill.
This ſhape can nought produce, that can offend.

sp.speaker: Luc,
sp.p: Pray you ſir, ſit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Not ſo far off, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You think I fear.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No, Sir; but I perceive, you are not confident of what you ſee.
Sir, recollect your ſelf; for what you heard
Before from theſe, was but what I directed,
With an intent indeed, to ſet off, as with a foil,
This mean but hearty entertainment.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I dare not truſt you, you ſpeak too well,
To mean well, ſince I am a ſtranger,
And no way have deſerved theſe favours.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: My Lady, Sir, hath told you truth.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Save your pains, leave us, I'le clear his underſtanding.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: The danger now approches, if ſhe be a witch.
Wickedneſſe deſires no witneſſe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sir, if ere you lov'd, which yet I wiſh you had not,
Then the diſcourſe I am to make, will with more eaſe
Approach your underſtanding, and ſoon gain belief.
I am a Lady as you ſee, not much deform'd;
The Servants and the ſtuff here are not borrowed,
Nor will it hurt my ſtate thus daily to entertain
Such, as I make my friends; and ſuch my birth is,
As bids me live thus without tax of pride.
I am mine own diſpoſer, no Parents to blame
My diſobedience, though my choice ſhould only
Pleaſe my ſelfe: They live not, or if they did,
My fortune was not wholly left by them.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You are in a happy ſtate, ſince you have power
To make ſome noble ſpirit fortunate, and you in him.
Sure ſhe is really what ſhe relates.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I might have been moſt happy, if my unlucky Starrs
Had not in one particular croſt me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your courteſie obliges me, to ask you wherein?
I vow ſhe weeps, the tears, like Orientall Pearls,
Drop from her eyes making a path down
Her moſt lovely cheeks, that may direct the looker on,
If loſt in wonder, as I am, to finde the way
Back to thoſe heavenly ſprings, from whence all treaſure
Flowes, rich above Tagus, or what poets ever fain'd.
Speak, gentle Lady, why this ſorrow?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: They are not tears of ſorrow, but of anger,
To ſee my liberty thus loſt, that liberty,
Which I have ſo much priſed, as ſome have thought
There was juſt cauſe to think me proud, and then to lay
My ſelfe and all my fortunes, even at mine enemies feet.
Oh miſery, have I not cauſe, think you, to weep,
And curſe my cruell Stars, that force me to do this?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe, 'tis a hard fate for to be ſubject
To ones enemy: But ſure your merits have the power to turn
That enmity to friendſhip, if you pleaſe.
Be plain, and let me know your meaning;
And, with the hazard of my life, I'le ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then thus: I hated you above all creature living,
The cauſe ſeek not to know, for 'tis impoſſible; nay came
With an intent to ſee you murder'd; but when I ſaw you
Though you then ſlept, the graces all, me-thought,
Dwelt in you face, and ſo protected you from harm;
That I that came with all that malice, became
Your ſole preſerver, and not content with that, ſtreight way
I made you abſolute commander of me and mine.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You amaze me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But not intending that you e're ſhould know me,
Nor the place of my abode, if you return'd not love,
I made my ſervants bring you thus blind fold
Hither, leſt you might boaſt my love hereafter.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Madam, 'tis a moſt ſtrange diſcourſe that you have made,
And yet you ſo deliver it, that I muſt think it
Truth; but what to anſwer, I am ignorant.
'Tis beſt I ſhould be plain, ſince you deſire to be ſo.
Then muſt you know, that my unhappy Starrs
Make me uncapable to receive the unequall treaſure,
Which you offer in your rich ſelfe. A Lady, like your ſelfe,
To ſay more fair, were falſe, hath long ſince rob'd
Me of the power, to be my own diſpoſer.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I fear'd indeed, that ſo much worth as you are Maſter of,
Could not be undiſpos'd of, ſince where's that woman
Would not uſe her utmoſt art, to gain a ſervant,
That ſhe might ſo juſtly glory in. I deſire to know
Her name yet, that I may pay her beauty and her wiſdome,
That reſpect it merits, for loving you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Madam, I muſt not; but, truſt me, ſhee's too wiſe to love
Me ſtill, for ſhe hath found me now of late, much 'much
Defective; but I do hope, my conſtancy will
Make ſupply; for, I vow, my affection and my life have
But one date.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Say you ſo, this proteſtation hath much leſſened
The opinion I held of your worth: Perhaps you ſay
This, to avoid my importunity, which I do too much
Apprehend. I am no raviſher; may be, when you ſhall ſee
Some greedily purſue what you do, with ſuch ſcorn, refuſe,
And thoſe perhaps your equalls, you'l finde too late,
You fondly have purſued your miſery, and fled
From a great happineſſe, and begin to make you
Feel your folly▪ I'le tie you to this hard condition,
As I believe you will account it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What is't, Lady? there's but one womans threatning,
That can affright me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Say you ſo, I'le try that; tell me that womans name,
The place of her abode, or by my hopes of happineſſe,
I'le make you the moſt miſerable man alive;
For, you ſhall never ſee again, what you ſo cov •• enjoy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You are witty in your anger, this is no ef •••… of that great love,
That you profeſt; it may be, time will make me
Better know your worth. Me-thinks you look m •… lovely
Then you did, though at the firſt fair.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Oh Sir, do you begin to flatter: Her name, name,
And with it, liberty; if you deny, to priſon.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No other way.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: None, as I live; can you expect from me, the injur'd,
Any favour? Could I invent a way more to afflict y ••
You ſhould be ſure to feel it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What ſhall I do? the choice is hard:
How can this any way advantage you?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: If ſhe be more deſerving than my ſelfe,
I ſhall not then repine to be refuſed; if leſſe,
Contemn you for your folly; and do not fear,
That I will make another partner of
The ſecret, which may be troubles you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: If I have not loſt it, I am happy; read the direction of this Letter.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Let's ſee't.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Aurelia made me ſo direct my Letters, ſo ••… deceive,
If any by misfortune ſhould be ſeen.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: To the fair hands of the moſt admired Lucinda.
How's this? he muſt not ſee my bluſhing, this cannot be.
It may; How? I am tranſported betwixt joy and fear?
Swear by the gods, Lucinda is the creature you moſt affect.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: There's no help, ſhee's too wiſe to be deceived.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come, ſwear.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: By Aurelia's ſelfe, the greateſt oath, I lvoe no other then Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: All my hopes thus again vaniſht. You are free,
And I the moſt unfortunate. Sir, you muſt be contented,
They bear you back as you came hither; and think,
What you have ſeen or heard, was but a dream.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thus I refuſe, cruell Aurelia, for thy ſake,
A beauty, that the powerfull gods might rivalls make.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, we muſt bear you many leagues hence.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Even where you pleaſe.
He's ſtark mad, with the conceit of his Favourits place.
You'l ne're make him know himſelfe.
The better: you ſee, he makes good ſport at Court.
Take heed, it may be there are ſome that do believe, you brought him to mock them.
If there be any there ſo ſimple to believe that, then I have perſonated thoſe I know not of, & I am glad on't
I, but to touch upon the name or actions of a Favourit, may bear equall danger with thoſe of Princes.

If this fool Favourit of ours do trouble any other, tell them, that Jewells receive their luſtre from a foyl; if then not ſatisfied, they're neer a kin to him in judgment, and envious to me; yet, I forgive them, knowing their malice cannot hurt my innocence, who rather wiſh to receive an injury my ſelfe, then touch at any, whoſe fooling is not their greateſt merit; I mean,
their onely hope of riſing. Here comes our Gallant.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Tell my Lords man, I am wondrous buſie, and cannot ſpeak with him theſe two hours.

sp.speaker: Man,
sp.p: I will, an't pleaſe your honour. He's ſtark mad, but I muſt humour him.
What Lord's man?
There's none to ſpeak with him, 'tis his fancy.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: In good faith, Sir, I cannot do't for you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I am very ſorry for't.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: I muſt not waſte my ſtock of favour, on ſo unreaſonable buſineſſes. Greater profit. I, ye ſay true; I know it will be the greater profit: But, Sir, 'twill likewiſe raiſe much envy againſt me, and I am not very well ſetled; the great men apprehend the danger of my riſing, and ſtudy how to give a ſtop to all my hopes.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Very like, Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, aſſure your ſelfe, in any other thing I ſhall be ready to ſerve you. Farewell, noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Now I muſt go.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Pox o'this coxcomb, why does he trouble me? Yet, 'tis good policy to ſpeak him fair to his face, I may have uſe of him. Pleaſe your grace, this is a friend of mine, a deſerving man.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Alas, Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: I humbly thank your grace. Your ſuit is granted.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Is it?

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p:
But with great difficulty. Sir, this mans ſuit is moſt impertinent, himſelf an idle, ill natur'd, and ſeditious fellow; I have known him long. Away, y'are ſawcy. Madam, your husband ſhall have the place, I vow 'tis for your ſake onely. Command you? no, Madam: I'le wait on you at your lodging, ſweet Madam.
Gentlemen, you muſt pardon me, I cannot hear you now, you ſee his grace hath ſent for me in haſte, pray tell him that I come. You are importunate, Get the Coach there hoe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.
This is direct madneſſe, and yet he ſpeaks more ſenſe, than ere he did in his life, but that he ſpeaks to no body.
Nay, th'Aſs is ſtrangely mixt; ſometimes he will have ſtarts of wit, that would almoſt couſen a man.
He would paſſe for a very accompliſhed Gentleman amongſt ſome women; but that his hoping to be a Favourit diſcovers him.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Slave, not my Coach ready?
What, the ſcene's chang'd now, the Lady is Sprat again.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: My Coach, thou cur.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How many horſes, Sir?

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Six, thou peaſant.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: An't pleaſe your honour, will not Cut, and your father's dung-Cart ſerve to day, I'le be the Coachman.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Be dumb, thou traitor, doſt thou not know, Obedience, not advice, belongs to ſervants; but I will teach thee how to be malepert, thou Brock.
Nay, Sir, for this time let me beg his pardon; beſides, Sir, ſpend not your rage ſo poorly. Hark you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: How?
It muſt be ſo, your reputation is in danger elſe; a Favourit muſt be noble, of a great ſpirit, careleſſe of danger.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p:
Why, Sir, then I am right; I care ſo little for
danger, I would ne're come near it; and if danger approach me, it had better keep farther off, it ſhall be ſure of cold entertainment.
You are wiſe, Sir, I believe it.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.l: Wiſe, I would have you know,
Ere all be done, the world ſhall think me ſo.

sp.p: I, Sir, we find the weight of it.

div.head: Actus quartus.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: HOW ſtrange a fortune have I run, ſince I did leave
The Court; but it moſt vexes me, to be ungratefull to
Her, that ſav'd my life, though not by love; yet there
Might be ſome other way to ſerve her, did I know
Her name. Why, ſure me thinks I'me free, ſince 'tis her will,
That barrs me from the means, to know her. I have
No comfort left, but in the faithfull friendſhip of the Prince.
His Siſter is become cruell, I fear unconſtant.
Adraſtus, how will he entertain me?

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: Ha, is't his ghoſt, or he himſelfe? he lives I my hopes are vain.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What means he, he cannot ſuſpect 'twas I that overcame him.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: I muſt diſſemble. My deareſt friend, where have you been
Theſe many daies? How it joyes me to have you in theſe arms?
A Serpent or a Fury had been more welcome.
The Court, Sir, languiſhes in your abſence, and reaſon,
Wanting you, the luſtre of it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Rather in your ſickneſſe, Sir; Now you are well, it will recover quickly.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: You have heard, it ſeemes, of my dyſaſter.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I heard, Fortune envying your worth, became your enemy.
But, was the Combat equall, had he no odds in Horſe nor Armes?

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Something there was in that, but my reſpect to the Princeſſe
Was moſt prejudiciall to me; yet ſince, ſhe hath
Requited me, with ſo much love and care of my health,
That I eſteem my ſelfe moſt happy to have received thoſe wounds
And with them, ſuch aſſurance of her affection.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: I'l vex his ſoul with jealouſie?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: If he accuſe me for theſe words, I'le combat him,
And ſo recover my honour loſt, or loſe my life.
'Twas fortune, not his valour, that o' recame me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Oh woman, woman, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Philanthus, what is't that troubles you? if any ſecret griefe,
Diſcover it to me, whom you may boldly truſt;
For I have told you, what to no other creature
Living I would diſcover, though wrack'd.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I am wrack'd indeed.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: Come, ſpeak man, be free, my friendſhip to you does command it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I am of a ſudden ſick.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: And that's my caſe: How I could hug my ſelfe for this?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Your pardon, Sir, I am not very well, I'le to my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: Shall I wait on you?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: A fine excuſe, alaſſe poor ſhallow lover.
Fortune, why doſt thou thus aſſiſt an ignorant
Againſt me? Why ſhould ſhe love him, and neglect me
Thus, that am ſo much in Art his Maſter? he has a ſmoother face,
And more youth about him; th'Adamants,
That draw a giddy Lady. I ſee him comming back,
I do not like it; I'le make as if I did not ſee him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Friend. He goes away. Adraſtus.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: I cannot hear.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He will not hear. How baſe a wretched thing
Is a diſſembler of which Adraſtus is the chiefe.
With what a ſhew of love he entertain'd me,
As if his ſoul were joy'd at ſight of me;
When by the lie he did invent of me, and of the Princeſſe,
I know he hates me: What a madneſſe is it then in me,
To believe that, which he ſpoke of her love to him;
He's ſure too cunning to diſcover it, if it were true,
To me eſpecially. Child that I was, I now finde out his plot,
Suffering my paſſion to give him an aſſurance
Of my affection to Aurelia, which before
He onely could ſuſpect.—See the ſweet Prince.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Thou partner of my ſoul, where haſt thou been?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oh Sir, the ſtrangeſt fortune hath befalln me, ſince
I received your Letter, that ever man encountred,
Too long to be told you now. But how go matters at Court?
What ſay they of the ſtranger, I mean, of me?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: My ſiſter moſt unjuſtly hates you, and no perſwaſions
Can as yet alter her, as y'are a ſtranger too.
I left her with a Gipſie and his daughter, who tells
The ſtrangeſt things that e're were heard; indeed he tels
You almoſt what you can deſire to know, mens fortunes paſt,
And, I think, that which is to come too, if he pleaſe:
Sure hee's really a Conjurer,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I long to ſee and talk with this rare man,
But more your beautious ſiſter, if ſhe will dain
To caſt her heavenly eyes on ſo deſpis'd a ſubject.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Come, fear it not, time will pacifie that unjuſt anger,
That ſhe conceiv'd againſt you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I fear ſhe is unconſtant.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: If ſhe love any other, nay, if ſhe love not Philanthus,
She's no more my ſiſter, but in name; a ſtranger
To my blood and my affection.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I do fear, if there be any body by, they'l diſcover
By my diſtemper, the affection, which except to your dearſelfe,
I have from all concealed.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: It ſhall be as you deſire it. Come, leave theſe down-caſt looks;
I could complain of my hard fate in love;
Here's a greater witneſſe of my Miſtreſſe ſcorn than ever,
She almoſt ſwears here never to love me;
There was ſome hope before, but I forget.
Each one in his owne cauſe is tedious,
Taxes an other that's guilty in the ſame.

div.stage: Enter Aurelia, Adraſtus, Miranthe, Linda, and a Gipſie.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Come, Sir, what can you ſay to this hand?

sp.speaker: Gip.
sp.l: You have been much in love, and there was cauſe
You ſhould be ſo, your ſervant was moſt worthy.
But you of late have been unkinde, perhaps
You love another; I can, but will not tell you at this time.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: This is partly truth. Shew him your hand.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I defie him to tell any thing of me.

sp.speaker: Gip.
sp.l: Y'are a good dull ſoul, you neither think of love nor hate;
To wait upon your Lady is all your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: In troth 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Lind.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, look on mine.

sp.speaker: Gip.
sp.l: Y'are wondrous amorous, and have already chang'd
Three Servants, the better for the worſe ſtill.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Upon my knowledge, Sir, you have told moſt certain truth.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: 'Save yee, ſiſter. Can this man tell any thing?
Sir, ſhew your skill on me, but to my ſelfe;
I would not have them heare what you conjecture:
More I know you cannot of no mans fortune.

sp.speaker: Gip.
sp.l: You'l ſtraight believe the contrary, your hand's
So eaſie, that I could almoſt tell every particular
Of your whole life; at leaſt, your paſſages
Of love, which is the skill that I profeſſe.
