sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Let's hear.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Adraſtus, hath he ſeen your hand yet?

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: No, Madam, 'tis to no purpoſe, he can tell nothing.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I am not of your minde. It ſeemes my brother
Will not have us know his fortune.

sp.speaker: Gip.
sp.l: You were in love at ſeven years old, as much as that age
Could admit, and have continued the moſt conſtant living,
Upon the ſmalleſt hopes; and 'tis not long ſince
You received a great diſcouragment, yet ſtill you love,
And much I fear in vain.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: 'Tis true, this makes me admire your skill.

sp.speaker: Gip.
sp.l: You are as true a friend, as y'are a lover too,
And you in that will be unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: It is impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Gip.
sp.p: I may fail, but I ſpeak according to my art.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: What think you of him?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: I think him a rare man.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: I'le ſee if he can make me think him ſo.
Now, Sir, ſhall I intreat you to ſhew your skill.

sp.speaker: Gip.
sp.p: You will not have me ſpeak aloud.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: Why not aloud?

sp.speaker: Gip.
sp.l: I will not; you have been a lover more then once, and ſtill
Unfortunate; firſt, by your own unconſtancy, your quarells
Too, have been no advancement to your reputation lately;
And more diſgraces ſhall light on you, till you return
Unto your firſt affection: the gods are much diſpleaſed.
Be good, and reconcile your ſelfe to heaven.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: A ſtrange fellow, but I'le ſeem to contemn him.
The moſt ignorant might have told what he tells me,
Of which number I believe him one.

sp.speaker: Gip.
sp.p: Say you ſo, pray let me ſee your hand once more.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: Well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gip.
sp.l: Your own arme being too weak to defend you againſt your enemy,
I finde, you baſely have employed the armes of others.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Gip.
sp.p: I finde ſomething like a murder written in this Line.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: This fellow is a devill; beſides, I ſee my falſhood does not thrive.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What ſaies he to you?

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: He is indeed a rare man, and I recant,
And much eſteem him and his skill.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: I ſee he has told you things that pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: He has ſo.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Siſter, if you love me.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Well, you know I can deny you nothing; I would not ſee him elſe.
How I long to ſpeak with him, yet I'le torment him too.
It troubles me to think, my brother divides
The channell of his love, which elſe would wholly
Run in one continued ſtream to me.
I eſteem you learned above all thoſe I ever ſaw or heard of.
This evening, Sir, wee'l talk at better leaſure.
Now I deſire all to retire and leave me.
Now, brother, where is Philanthus?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Friend.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How I tremble: Were I to enter Combat againſt a Lion,
Nay, againſt an Hoſte of men, me-thinks I ſhould not
Be thus fearfull. I know, 'tis not my part
To play the paſſionate Lover, ſhee'l laugh at me.
But I have loſt that power I had over my paſſion,
By her unkindneſſe, nor can I hide the ſorrows of my heart.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Whither, ſiſter, did not you promiſe to hear him?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Yes, but I ſee nothing but a ſtatue, there's neither
Sound nor motion comes from that.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: It is your cruelty that hath transform'd me then.
Dear Madam, tell me, from what can grow this alteration?
If any falſe report have done it, 'tis great injuſtice
To believe an enemy wronging a friend, and not
To hear that friend firſt anſwer for himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Philanthus, I do not complain at all, why do you go about
To juſtifie your ſelfe, before you be accuſed?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Madam, why am I then baniſhed from
Your preſence, and your favour?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: 'Twas your occaſion drew you from the Court,
For ought I know; and for my favour, I never
Doated on you, nor do I hate you now.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Yet, ſiſter, this cold anſwer does not become
That love, which you, on my knowledge, deſir'd,
That he ſhould think you bear him.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Brother, I muſt acknowledge, that I love and honour Philanthus merits;
But yet, I take it, I never ſo far did engage my ſelfe,
As not to be my own diſpoſer; and you too far
Intereſt your ſelfe, in being more a friend to him than me.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Aur
sp.l: You blind my judgment, which ſhould wholly direct me in my choice:
For he whom you commend of reaſonable parts,
Muſt from me gain reſpect above the beſt deſerver.
And much I wonder, that Philanthus will call in queſtion
His own merits, for ſo he does in my opinion, to uſe you,
As a ſecundary means, ſince if he be a man deſerves my love,
I hope he thinks, that I have wit to know it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Madam, 'twere ignorance in me, or any other, to plead other
Deſert, than readineſſe to obey; and fortune enviouſly
To me, hath ſtill denyed ſuch an occaſion, as might let you ſee,
The greateſt danger ſhould to me ſeem none,
Where I might hope to do you any ſervice.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Your promiſes are large, and I may perhaps
Meet with employment.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Madam, if ſo, I ſhall beleeve my ſelfe moſt happy.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Well, dear ſiſter, uſe him kindly.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Brother, you did deſire, that I ſhould give him hearing,
sp.l: None by but you: I will exceed that favour,
And wiſh to enjoy his company alone; pray leave us.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Moſt willingly.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You may ſtay, Sir, if you pleaſe, except you fear
To be alone with me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Madam, why fear, what danger?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: More then you think, I muſt impart a buſineſſe to you
In which I ſhall make tryal of
The great love that you profeſſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I am bleſt, if you be ſerious; though I ſhould
Periſh in what you employ me, I muſt
Account my end moſt fortunate.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You muſt ſwear to perform what I enjoyne you,
According to your power.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Madam, I vow't, if it be not againſt mine honour.
I value you above my life, but leſſe then that.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: One exception more, and then be what it will.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Not to command me to ceaſe to love you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Oh! fear it not; and yet I will not promiſe to love you,
Not when you have performed, what I ſhall now enjoyne;
Yet, I confeſſe, the ſervice will be moſt acceptable:
Nor muſt you make my Brother, though your deareſt friend,
Partaker of the ſecret.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: That's worſt of all.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Swear.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Then know, that I do hate that Knight, that overcame Adraſtus,
More then I love my beauty or my health.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: This cannot chuſe but pinch him. And do enjoyne you
By your oath, to find him out, and ſo deliver him into my hands,
That I may have ſtill power to puniſh him as I think fit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And, Madam, wherefore do you hate him? I heard,
His actions did not deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: For his diſcourteſie, and neglect of me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Know you of what Country he is?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oh, Madam, I finde your plot, you know you ſhall
Still be importuned by my love, which will
Not give me leave, to let you live in peace;
And therefore you have ſet me on this uſeleſſe task.
You are witty in your cruelty.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Not onely ſo, for I deſire to be reveng'd upon that Knight.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Will't content you if I kill him?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: No, his puniſhment I reſerve unto my ſelf,
The way to bring him hither, to your own diſcretion;
By force, or by entreaty, as you pleaſe. And ſo I leave you.
Think on your oath, remember too I promiſe no reward.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Nor may I hope one neither.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You are your own diſpoſer.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: At leaſt allow me this encouragement.
Why ſhould I ſtrive to pleaſe this ſcornfull ſhe, that hates me;
Nay, hates me, when I do deſerve all love?
The beautious Lady of the Caſtle did not ſo.
Am I not by the gods thus puniſhed, for my ingratitude to her? yes.
Certainly, ſhe ſav'd my life: Her beauty is not much inferiour,
Her wit ſeemes equall; how e're, ſhe ought
To be eſteemed by me much more. But where's ſhe,
Or what is ſhe, I know not, onely
I feel her growing here, here, in my heart.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: This cuſtome ſhall no longer be of uſe;
The laſt Combat was granted, it ſeemes,
Hath drawn on this.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Your Court will be diſhonoured by the refuſall.
Shall it be ſaid, You protect thoſe, who do wrong
To others, when the guilt perhaps makes them
Too feeble to defend themſelves.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Well be it as you will, I am innocent
Of any blood, that ſhall this day be ſhed.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Let the Knight enter.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: How, Gudgen my favourit? nay, then there's no great danger: Meant you 'twas he? Which of the women will he challenge?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Nay rather, how many men at all theſe weapons.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Speak your proſe firſt, and ſee you be not our before you begin your leggs.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
No, I warrant you, Sir, I'le make my 〈…〉
rences very ſweetly.

sp.speaker: Age,
sp.p: Something long a beginning.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Take heed your tongue do not diſcover you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No, nor my tail neither, I warrant you, as 〈◊〉 tell it.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Remember, born a great way off.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I, I, and not chriſtened; for you are a T ••… you know.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Now he begins.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Moſt doughty Duke. Maſter, what muſt I call you?

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Shouldſt not name me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Moſt doughty Duke, my Maſter Coxcomb whom you ſee.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Oh ſlave.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Is come to Court, to ſhew his chivalry againſt.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Speak ſoftly.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Againſt ſpeak-ſoftly, ſervant to your grace.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Bernardo, ſervant to your grace, you fool.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Bernardo, ſervant to your grace, you fool whom if he be within this diſmall place, I him defie throwing the monſtrous lie into his ugly throat.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Good poetry.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And ſhould he come, I would not be ins coat:
For ſure my Maſter, who is come thus far,
Will kill him dead before he be aware.
I am his mouth, and I do tell you from him,
My Maſter, if he come, will ſoundly bum him.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Wooll a?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And therefore keep away, if you be wiſe,
Till I my Trumpet have forth-ſounded thrice.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Me-thinks the Knight ſhould ſpeak for himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: I do not underſtand a word of your language.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Hard luck, how far was your Knight born?

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Be ſure you ſay far enough, they 'I know me elſe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I warrant ye. Beyond the worlds end.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: How many miles may that be?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Forty good miles, and more. His Father?

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Peace, ſound again, I am in ſome fear.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Hee'l learn to ſpeak anone.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: It ſeemes the enemy dares not approach; if he do, I'le ſend him after thoſe ten Knights that I kill'd in Thrace, ſingly, man after man, though they aſſaulted me all at once.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: That's ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: I, at one blow, with this ruſty ſword, ruſty with being continually imbrued in blood of bruitiſh beaſts,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Indeed he kill'd a mad Bullock once.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Clove to the teeth a monſtrous high and mighty maſtiff Dog, of a Leminian Lion's hide.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: A Cow's perhaps, his father was a Butcher.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Sound the third time. Not yet, how baſe is he, that dares do injurie, but much more baſe, that dares not juſtifie his wickedneſſe. Not yet?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Now he ſpeaks plain.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: I with this Gun have kill'd a monſtrous Wren.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: He come! Hang him coward.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Oh that he durſt, then would I. What noiſe is that?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: I thirſt for blood, if there be any here.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: To drink, would he have it?

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: That dare according to antient books, maintain the beauty of his Lady againſt mine. Since the enemy dare not appear, I muſt be in action.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Where's yours?

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: My ſquire here ſhal be ſhe, my valour ſhal ſupply that which wants in beauty.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: None dares. I am weary of this fool.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.l: Dare none encounter me, march quite away?
He's come, but 'tis too late, I ſcorn to ſtay.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: What did you come for?

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.l: I will tell you the ſecret, I did come hitherto no end,
And I do mean to depart to as little purpoſe.
Therefore like other Knights, that make a ſhow
In glittering Armour, as I came I go.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Call him back again, hee's a rank coward.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: No, let him alone, I'me weary; beſides the day is far ſpent,
And we do loſe much better ſport; nor were it well
To have him ſo diſcouraged.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let me enjoy your friend Gudgen's company ſometimes.

sp.speaker: 1. C.
sp.p: Madam, I'le fit him the beſt I can to make you ſport.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: If Philanthus conceal from Agenor
What I enjoyn'd, he loves me more then him,
Which I ſhall much rejoyce in.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Is this your friendſhip?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Do not accuſe me, where I am not guilty.
The ſecret is not mine, that's truſted by another to me:
And when it does concern them more then me,
Yet ſo much I am touched, that I do burſt
With a deſire to tell you.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Why do you not?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: She bound me by an oath to the contrary, moſt cunningly;
For elſe, ſhe knew I would have told it, you.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Philanthus, I ſee ſhe hath wholly won you from me,
And I am glad you need not uſe my friendſhip further.
Which of you two to accuſe of moſt unkindneſſe,
I know not well. For me, I ſhould not have entertain'd
The knowledge of a ſecret, on a condition ſo prejudiciall
To our friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'T were great injuſtice in you, if't ſhould.
A perjur'd man would ill become your friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: You tell it to no man in telling me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Had not her tongue, her action did enjoyn me to keep it from your
Knowledge of all men; you ſaw, ſhe did deſire your abſence.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Perhaps ſhe fear'd to ſpeak before me, that which yet ſhe would
Be well content, that I ſhould know from you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: If I have friendſhip, the knowledge of it, if you love me,
Would more afflict you, than my denyalls does.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Such an excuſe does worſt of all: farewell.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sure Aurelia ſo much hates me, that ſhe envies me
That happineſſe of her brothers friendſhip, and onely
Did invent this plot to break it. Stay, Sir, I'le give you proof
That I dare truſt you with a ſecret, and you will
Say, a ſtrange one though not this.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Well, what is't?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I do not love your ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: No otherwiſe then as ſhe is your ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: This makes me more ſuſpect your friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why ſhould you think I love her, ſince ſhe hates me,
And laies plots to deprive me of your friendſhip,
Which, by the gods, I priſe above what happineſſe
Women can bring me.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: This proteſtation makes me think, you do not love indeed.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Be not miſtaken, I do love.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Remember my paſt fortune with the beautious Lady
Of the Caſtle, and you will finde, that I have cauſe
To be a Lover, if only out of gratitude.
Your ſiſter's cruelty hath made my reaſon
Once more Maſter of my will; and being ſo;
I cannot chuſe, but ſee my former folly,
In hoping to enjoy ſo abſolute a creature
As Aurelia is, whom heaven ordaines
For one of greater merits; the gods had been
Indeed unjuſt, to make unworthy me the centre,
Where ſo much worthy loves ſhould meet, the leaſt
Of which, is ſure to make the beſt deſerver happy.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Philanthus, my friendſhip's of that nature, that it does
Glew me unto your deſignes; and ſince I ſee
My ſiſter hath given over to deſerve your love,
I muſt confeſſe, I think you could not place it with more reaſon,
Than on this Lady. 'Tis true, that I would have thee ſtill a Lover
Like my ſelfe, for ſo you'l hear me, and not laugh,
When I deplore my miſery in love; and I do glory,
To be found more conſtent than you are. The ſcorns
Of my Miſtreſſe have not altered me; I think
It vice to change, how ere ſhe uſes me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Rather 'tis vice not to change, when reaſon does command it.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Reaſon can never be your warrant to be falſe.
I had been falſe to reaſon and my ſelfe both,
To love where I ſhould finde neglect yet,
Where I love, 'tis with much paſſion, but
Not your blind-fold conſtant way.

sp.speaker: Age
sp.l: Nor would I that you ſhould. I ſhall be happy
In your happineſſe, or you in mine, if either
Of our different waies do proſper. But you
Now love you know not whom, nor know you where to finde her.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pardon me, the skilfull Moor, late come to Court,
Aſſures me, that he will let me ſee again
That Lady by his art.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: When this?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This morning I ſent my man before to tell him,
I am comming; his houſe is here hard by.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: May I not ſee her too?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Perhaps, if you diſguiſe you like my ſervant.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Let's go then, I know he does expect me.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, my Maſter will ſtreight be here.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: Sir, I am ready.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Great Maſter of your art, good-morrow.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: Good-morrow, noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I hardly yet believe it poſſible,
You ſhould perform what you have undertaken.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: More, Sir, if I pleaſe: I am in ſubſtance
What others ſeem; nor ſhall you ſtay
The making of a Circle. But who's this with you?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: A ſervant, Sir, that I dare truſt.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Pardon me, Sir, I have reaſon to be wary.
This art is no waies lawfull; for telling fortunes,
That I count nothing. Is there nought elſe that you deſire?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Stand by then. By that great power that's given me,
I charge thee, the form of that Lady, to
Appear, that this Prince deſires, ſo habited,
As when he ſaw her laſt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oh ye powers, 'tis ſhe. I muſt confeſſe, your art
Is inimitable, 'tis the ſame form; me-thinks
It looks ſo like the life, that it would ſpeak,
If I ſhould queſtion it: no beauty can be greater.
Shee's gone, can you not once more ſhew her.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: Yes, and much more, if I were pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: What? ſit down and you ſhall ſee. Return thou beauteous ſhadow.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: She's by much fairer then Aurelia; I was a fool
To purſue what's fled, and to refuſe a bleſſing
Offered like this; ſhe ſmiles, as if ſhe underſtood me,
And confirm'd my ſaying.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Although I burſt, I'le ſee the end.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: When firſt I ſaw what's here preſented, I
could not think ſhe was the thing ſhe ſeem'd,
And now I cannot think ſhe is a ſhadow,
But a ſubſtance,—That ſigh aſſures me,
That ſhee's fleſh and blood; and yet a Daemon
May poſſeſſe a body, making it move by its own Organs.
A dead Body, not a living body: pardon, if ſhadow,
Or if ſubſtance, this bold touch; it is not profane,
Since it proceeds from an affection, equall
To what a mortall ere could boaſt of, in ſo ſhort a time.
This ſoft and warm hand does aſſure me, you are
That noble Lady, to whoſe courteſie I owe
My life, and now again it is within your power
To ſee me die. But if you ſhall once more, make me a tender
Of that love, which at your Caſtle I refus'd,
As being then a priſoner to anothers beauty.
Aſſure your ſelfe, I ſhall redeem that errour,
With an affection equall to your merits, paying the debt
Of two lives that I owe you, and this of love the greater.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Oh falſe friend.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: She anſwers not. I fear I all this while, tranſported
By my paſſion, have ſpoken to a ſhadow.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Rather I fear your proteſtations will prove ſuch.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: 'Tis ſhe, and I am miſerable.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oh my joy. No, Madam, they are as firm as are the Poles,
sp.stage: Here the Gipſie pulls off his beard.
sp.l: That prop up heaven; and can I doubt? the proofs
That you have given me of your love, are infinite,
In that you thus diſguiſe your ſelfe thus once more
T'ingage me in an infinite affection, which I deſire to ſeal thus.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Will you not think you, recall your vowes,
When you ſhall know my name.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Cruell woman, thou needſt not tell him, he too well knowes
Thou art Lucinda; the unkind Miſtreſſe of his
Too kind, and much wronged friend Agenor.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Lucinda, Oh my croſſe fortune, I am falſe and knew it not.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Excuſe it not, but juſtifie thy ſelf,
That I may kill thee without repining.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You know I never ſaw ſaw her.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: True. But was it poſſible thou couldſt believe,
That I could be tranſported with that paſſion
For any other beauty, then for that thou ſeeſt in her?
How often, raviſhed with admiration, did I deſcribe
Her face, and thought by love, like the muſt cunning Painter,
To draw her very feature to thy underſtanding,
sp.stage: All this while, after their ſwords are drawn, the Gipſie and the Lady perſwade and hold the Prince.
sp.l: As they do to the ſight; ſo much at leaſt,
As if thou hadſt but been that friend,
Which I did hope, it would have prompted thee to fear
No other but Lucinda could have been ſo fair.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Y'are paſſionate without all reaſon, and
Forget friendſhip. Hear me.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: No, I am too tame, ſuffering thee, that haſt
Nothing, but the empty name of friendſhip,
Thus to abuſe me and ſhall that be a ſufficient
Bridle to hold back my revenge? Draw thy ſword.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Why, you are mad.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I fear ſome ill event.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Why ſmile you? Think you, becauſe my valour is not like to yours,
The ſubject of each tongue, my maiden-ſword,
Never unſheathed till now, that I do fear
In a juſt cauſe to uſe it? Provide your beſt defence.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Defence, hear me.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Come, draw, and do not dally. Your guilt hath
Made you weaker then you think, you are not
What you were, when you were faithfull.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If I have any power, let me conjure you.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: You have none.
sp.stage: Here, ſhe breaks from the Gipſie.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hear me.—How do you noble Sir: Oh for a Chirurgeon

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Ha! what have I done?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis in vain, I am well, well as I could have wiſh'd
I am remov'd from being a hinderance to
My friend in his affection. You perceive
How much he loves you, ſince it did force him
To make a ſacrifice of me, me, his better halfe.
Sir, give me your hand; it was my fortune, not my will,
That croſt you in this Ladies love. And, Madam,
Remember, that my laſt breath is employ'd,
To aſſure you, that I ſhall never reſt
In peace, if any other ſhall poſſeſſe that place,
Which you thought me worthy to hold, in your affection,
Then this Prince, who onely does deſerve it;
To whom, I hope, my weak defence, may juſtifie my innocence.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Thou cruell murtherer of thy friend, who rather than
Endanger thee, would not defend himſelfe. Thou cruell Butcher.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I fear I have been too raſh.
He no way did employ his ſword.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh cruell fate. Gon, he's gone for ever.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: He's quite dead, and you are hurt too, I think. Ha!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: A ſcratch.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: He did employ his laſt breath to gain my love,
From you too; did he not?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He did, but 'tis in vain, for I ſhall hate thee more then a Serpent.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Yet leſſe then I ſhall do my curſed ſelfe,
The vildeſt monſter of ingratitude,
That the earth ever bore: I wonder why
It does not gape, and ſwallow me alive.
'Tis mockery to believe the gods are juſt,
After this ſufferance: Here, if you have any mercy, kill me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: I'le do't my ſelfe then.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, for heavens ſake.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Thou ignorant, 'twas to pleaſe heaven I would have done it.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: You are deceived, they want not proper inſtruments;
If 'twere their divine pleaſure to ſhed your blood,
To ſhew their juſtice: No they delight in mercy more.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: But not ſo far as to confound their juſtice,
I am no ſubject for it.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: Madam, your help, to ſave another miſchief.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Onely that thought makes you unfit, y'are penitent already;
And that I may remove from you this black deſpair,
That darkens thus your underſtanding, know,
For your friends dear ſake, if e're I love again,
It ſhall be you, except his memory.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Fain I would die, yet fain I would believe her.
Oh love! what power thou haſt, that thus can change
My juſt revenge; although I know this proteſtation
Growes from a fear to offend his ghoſt, and not
From love to me, for that's impoſſible:
Yet, I will live, to inflict ſuch puniſhment
Upon my ſelfe, that you ſhall give me leave to die,
To end my miſery. The Tombe I will erect
For this dear Coarſe, ſhall well expreſſe my love,
Howe're, my unfortunate hand did ſhed his blood.
Let your care be beſtowed upon the body,
Till I diſpoſe of it; I ſhall reward your pain.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: My Lord, I will.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Heaven affects. Why do I live, and ſee him thus,
And I the Author? Madam, what is your pleaſure?
Will you remove unknown, or ſhall I wait
Upon you to your brother?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir, I beſeech you, give me leave to be my own diſpoſer.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Obedience is my ſacrifice.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But how, or where, is yet unknown to me,
Uncertain fate, yet certain miſery.

div.head: Actus quintus.

sp.p: WHat, are our Comedians ready?
Yes, yes.
That's well; the Princeſſe does walk preſently, and comming in unlook'd for, 't will pleaſe her the better. It's fine Poetry, is't not?
Onely faulty, if not fooliſh enough; a quarter of an houres work, when 'twas done; and yet I have ſtudied a long time; and can finde nothing more ridiculous,
Is there no prologue?

sp.l: No, there's too few Actors.—Here's the Princeſſe.
They have their one, they'l enter ſure.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: How now, what ſtrange hob-goblin's this?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Love, that intoxicates the brains of mortals, where there is any,
Here inhabits none to be intoxicated, 'tis well known.
Not Siſiphus, that reſtleſſe rowles the ſtone ſtill,
Takes more delight, then I do in my own fill.
My Phillida, lo where ſhe does appear,
More humble then a Peacock, or his peer,
The Turky, who with her briſtling plumes,
Confounds my ſenſe, and my poor heart conſumes.
Oh gods▪ Oh moſt glittering Wight,
Thou workſt upon me, I had need go write.
My paſſion, 'tis not a ſtumbling tongue,
That can expreſſe the love I bear thy bung.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.l: Kiſſe where thou lov'ſt, I thee pray, even here;
Nothing I have too pretious for my dear.
But you do fool me, I and frump me; you,
I Venus fair or chaſt; go too, go too.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Is Venus like to thee, thou durty ſow?
No, thou art like unto our brended Cow:
But yet I fear ſhe will prove wilder far,
Thou art incenſt, thy goblin eyes make war.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.l: Puh let me go, theſe come not from your heart;
Too late I finde you play the Courtiers part.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: May all the joyes of earth confound me, I,
Have dyed thy love, and live I will perdy.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.l: Oh perjur'd man, ſee where ſhe comes you wot of,
Betwixt you ſurely I am made a ſot of.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Sir, I am come to viſit you, and your fair Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Moſt odoriferous Lady, you are offenſibly welcome; for you have done me a moſt deſperate and intolerable favour; my Miſtreſſe does with me, I know, congratulate the miſchiefe.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Sir, I am a ſimple wench, that underſtand nothing beyond ſenſe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I am ſorry for it, yet I will deſcend to your underſtanding, and ſpeak none; or very little, hereafter.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: It will become your perſon.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Hark how ſhe woes my dear: Oh, I am loſt I fear.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Lady, you are ſad, and much I wonder, being ſo happy in your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Damoſell, you are unkinde, your ſcorns are ſcurvy, and become you not.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Oh thou art ſuch a pretty wench, I could wiſh my ſelfe a gib Cat, and we two together in the dark.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Ah me! he's loſt. Sir, you forget me, your Phillida.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Thee? I do contemn the thought of ſuch a dowdie.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Ah me, then let me die; thou conſtant wretch, maiſt thou ſink down to bliſſe; but ſhall I curſe, whom I have loved more, then my beſt Cow M • ll: Oh no. Come death and end my woe. But what ſhall finiſh my unhappy daies? this knife, this ſhall afford me paſſage to the ſhades below, where I will try by dying thus my love to ſhow, and fill his hard heartfull of diſmall wo.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Alas good fool.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Will you not ſave her?

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.l: Now I am dead, doſt thou not grieve, thou cruell elſe,
If I had known, I had not kill'd my ſelfe.
Now I am ſtark dead, pray tell him ſo.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Would thou wert buried, thou'lt ne're leave talking elſe.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Miranthe, this is ſo wofull a ſtory, I'le hear no more, make my excuſe to the dead Lady, when ſhe revives.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Maſter, Maſter, riſe, riſe.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: That's not my cue, he's out.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The Princeſſe is gone.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Gone is not my cue neither.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The play is done.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Thou lyeſt, I muſt be kis'd firſt; I wil I not open mine eyes till I be kis'd.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: What a coile's here, I could finde in my heart, now his eyes are ſhut, to undo my points, and give him his cue. Sir, Maſter. I think hee's a verier aſſe then my ſelfe, there let him lie, for me, I'le follow for a reward.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.l: Is he gone, had I no place about me worthy his kiſſe?
Then let me wake from death. Why this it is,
Since when I courted him, he would not come,
My Ghoſt ſhall haunt him, till he kiſſe my hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: This is the day, and this the place, that Philanthus
Intends to preſent himſelf as the ſtranger Knight,
To receive what puniſhment I ſhall inflict,
Where I will make him jealous of himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Why will you ſo torment him, ſince you confeſſe you love him.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Still to draw greater proofes of his affection, in which I glory.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Take heed, whilſt that you uſe him thus, you do not
Leſſen what you would make greater, his love.
Were I man and in his place, I ſhould have hated
You, for you in reaſon have appeared unworthy,
And inconſtant, which how his generous ſpirit
May brook, who knowes.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Púh theſe are needleſſe fears, ſee where he comes,
The ſame armes he wore, when he o're came Adraſtus;
A coldneſſe ſtrikes my heart at ſight of him.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: If you be the Princeſſe Aurelia, I was enjoyn'd
Thus low to bend my knee, lower my heart,
In my ſubmiſſion to your offended deity.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Yes, Sir, I am, and you I take to be the moſt
Diſcourteous Knight alive.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Madam, I have already paid for that offence,
The forfeit of my honour, if not to be recovered,
By faithfully performing what I was enjoyn'd,
Rather commanded, by your Philanthus, for ſuch
How e're you priſe him, he deſires to be eſteem'd.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: How well he counterfeits anothers voice.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: By a ſtrange accident he met me, and when
Perſwaſion would not move me, for I had a deſire
Another way, he did employ his not to be reſiſted valour,
Compelling me to ſwear, for ſafeguard of my life,
Here to preſent my ſelfe, and willingly receive
What puniſhment your rigour can inflict.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What cenſure do you expect?

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: Death, for I do believe you the moſt cruell Lady living.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Why do you think ſo?

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Your rigour to Philanthns, who partly made
Me know his ſtory, made me ſuſpect; yet ſtill
He loves you, more then his own ſoul. But your
Unjuſt hatred againſt me, gives me aſſurance,
Of your cruell nature.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Perhaps I did but ſeem to hate you, you feel am unarm'd
For puniſhment, none but my ſelfe, and one weak woman more.
But you are bound by oath to endure what ere
I ſhall inflict; I'le try him fully.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: I am, and wiſh to know my ſentence.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: With you own ſword I will perform it.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: Alas, you have not ſtrength to take my life, were I unarm'd.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Rather no will, you are not noble that would thus,
T' the danger of your life, perform your promiſe.
Receive your ſword, and know, I am ſo far
From hate, that I did love you, for the great reſpect
You ſhew'd me, though I ſeem'd otherwiſe.
But you retiring, and to me unknown,
Bar'd me from means to thank you, or let you know,
How much I lik'd your valour, which ſure by Philanthus
Could not be exceeded; I rather take it as a courteous act
From you to him, he hoping the performance
Of the task enjoyn'd, might reconcile him to my love,
Which is now impoſſible; yet, I did much affect him,
Till his boaſting did beget my hatred.
But truſt me, in his ſending you, how e're,
I thank him, he hath much prejudic'd himſelfe.
There is no honour that this Court can do you,
Which boldly you may not promiſe to your ſelfe.
Nor would I have you think I am unconſtant,
For I have ſtill profeſt to love, where I did find
Moſt worth, untill I were confin'd by Marriage.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Madam, however ſome will cenſure this your humour,
To me it does appear the beſt. I honour you,
And ſhall believe my ſelfe the happieſt creature
Living, in this your good opinion.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Longer, Sir, I will not hold you, but when you pleaſe
To viſit me at Court, theres no aſſurance
Of my affection, that I ſhall refuſe,
Which honour will permit me to beſtow.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: I, make me in my own opinion the mark of envy,
To the moſt happy living. Beſides, thus on your hand,
I ſeal my laſting ſervice.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Madam, what's your deſigne in this, to give Philanthus,
As a ſtranger, ſo large aſſurances of your affection,
And yet make him think, you hate him as he is himſelf.

sp.p: Ah! Madam, the moſt unfortunate accident.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: How! what? thou frighteſt me, ſpeak.
The Prince your brother.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What of him?
Hath kill'd his deareſt friend, noble Philanthus.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: 'Tis impoſſible, I know the contrary.

sp.l: Oh, Madam, 'tis too true, your brothers ſorrow is a witneſſe of it;
The Court is drown'd in tears, and juſtly,
It never felt a greater loſſe.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I have abuſed my ſelf then, made vowes and proteſtations
To I know not whom; the voice indeed was different.
But is this certain truth? were ye a witneſſe?
But how, or why, or when? I am amazed
With wonder and ſorrow. Speak.
'Tis ſo certain, that your brother would have kil'd himſelf,
Had he not been prevented.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: He had done well, 'tis fit we all ſhould die;
For who would live after Philanthus.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You Gods, was't not ſufficient miſery for me
To love a man, whom I had never ſeen before?
His heart given to another, or ere he knew me?
But that you afterwards muſt raiſe me to the happineſs
Of his affection, and then thus violently pull
Him from me. Why ſhould you thus oppoſe your ſtrongeſt powers
Againſt a ſilly woman. But, love, I know it is thy malice,
That did invite the cruell deſtinies to cut
The fine ſpun thread of dear Philanthus, and cruelly
Lengthen mine. You powers, it is enough; for you have humbled
My proud heart low as the earth. Seek out ſome other,
That hath not felt your ſcourges, I confeſſe
Your power, and am obedient too. But why ſhould I
Begin to flatter unjuſt heaven, within whoſe power
It does not lie to pleaſure me. Philanthus gone,
Whoſe name I'le reverence more in their deſpight,
Then all the envious deities, that took him from me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Impious, cruell, and forgetfull woman, thy ſacrilegious
Thoughts and words, I ſee, have been the cauſes,
That have ſtopt my paſsage to the Elizium fields,
Forcing me thus wandring to ſtay above the earth,
To feel torments above neglect in love;
Nay, equall to thoſe helliſh pangs, bred from the thoughts
Of a much lov'd inconſtant Miſtreſs. But I'le revenge
My ſelfe, by haunting thee perpetually.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Oh thou dear ghoſt, ſuch a revenge were ſweet,
I ſhould deſire to look upon thee ever.
After I had thee, thou wert ſoon loſt, I was not ſatisfied.
Let me if poſſible embrace thee, at leaſt
Converſe with thee for ever thus.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I ſee you have forgot my laſt requeſt.
Think on the Prince, in whom I live; this way ye croſs
The ordinance of heaven, who never failes
To puniſh diſobedience, from me. If you
Be ſlack in loving him, my ghoſt ſhall never reſt
In peace; and when I next appear, a thouſand furies
Will come along, and in your ſight torment me,
Paſt what a mortall can imagin, if not for love
Of him, for love of me. Be pittifull, and free me
From an endleſs miſery. Go to my Tomb,
Where daily you ſhall finde him weeping:
There make an offer of your ſelfe, in recompence
Of all his ſufferings; this done, you may be happy.
But if refuſ'd, the height of miſery will fall upon you,
To me, perpetuall torment; remember,
On me perpetuall torment.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Stay, ſtay, and hear me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: My time is paſt, remember laſting torment.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis vaniſh'd, cruell ghoſt, that doſt conjure me,
sp.l: Thus unkindly to forſake my firſt love, inconſtancy's avice,
They do not love at all, that can love twice.
'Tis to me impoſſible, which if I do it not, I ſhall be miſerable.
And in doing it, I ſhall be ſo too then 'tis indifferent:
Oh no, I ſhall releaſe from miſery,
And happy make the ghoſt of Philanthus;
That thought alone o'recomes me.
Strange friendſhip when the ghoſt of him that's dead,
Shall for the living with ſuch reaſon's plead.

sp.p: Where is the Prince? is he yet ſo tranſported with ſorrow?

sp.l: I ne're ſaw man ſo torment himſelfe. 'Tis true; Philanthus
Deſerv'd to have as many tears ſhed for him,
As any Prince that liv'd, but yet, that being paſt,
And ſorrow fruitleſſe, me-thinks the ſorrow ſhould grow leſſe.
If it be poſſible, it does receive increaſe.
Some ſay, the Princeſſe Aurelia bears a part too.
Wheres the old Duke? followed his children to the Tomb
Of Philanthus: Never ſuch a ſorrow ſeen in Millain.
In duty we are bound to wait upon them,
Both with our perſons and our ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Me-thinks this ſacred ground, that does contain
The body of my friend, ſhould open it ſelf,
And give me leave once more to embrace him,
If his dear ghoſt be' concil'd; and if it hate me,
Why ſhould not then the earth, in friendſhip
To its now inhabitants, gape wide and ſwallow me
Alive, for my baſe act? How often have the gods
Made even the inſenſible elements, the executioners
Of their juſtice, againſt a murtherer, and a more
Hatefull one was never performed: murder'd my friend,
Oh baſe! and ſuch a friend, that even in death
Expreſt himſelfe above my malice. The wound
This ſword hath made in his noble & undefenc'd breaſt
Was only like a vent to a full veſſell,
That ſo the ſtream of his unequall love might finde
The freeer paſſage. Why ſhould I live then, to be the hatefull,
And contemn'd example of ingratitude, to all poſterity?
And I will daily ſacrifice my ſorrowes and my tears
Upon his Tombe, 'twill not ſerve. Were I a woman,
Water might waſh my guilt off; but as I am a man,
A manly ſacrifice muſt expiate my fault.
Blood muſt be ſatisfied with blood. Philanthus,
Receive this ſacrifice, I will revenge the murder.

sp.p: Deer my Lord, what would ye do?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Nothing, why do ye hinder?
Who made you my controulers?

sp.p: Heaven forbid, that we ſhould ſuffer you.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: For friendſhip ſake, give me my ſword, why ſhould you
Keep me hereto torment me? in death I ſhould find eaſe.
If any of you had a minde to die, and knew 'twould be for your content,
Think you I would be ſo diſcourteous to diſturb you?
You need not hold me, you may give me freedom,
Now I have no weapon, you cannot hinder me to weep
Theſe curſed eyes out; by whoſe falſe lights,
falſe to my ſoul, came in that beauty of Lucinda,
Whoſe violence working by jealouſie, forced me
To murder my deareſt deareſt friend. Pardon love,
I have blaſphem'd againſt thy deity, for which I know,
His Ghoſt will hate me more then for his wounds.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Hence hypocrite, doſt thou not fear his wounds
Should ope themſelves, and blead his ſearcloath through,
At thy approach.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Siſter, you cannot pronounce words half ſo harſh
As I deſerve, nor tax me with a guilt ſo great,
But I'le acknowledge more, but not the ſame
Which you accuſe me of: For, were the ſorrow
Of the world joyn'd in one for Philanthus,
Mine might be thought a worthy rivall,
Nay, exceed that far.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Oh Philanthus.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: But ſiſter, you, why you, why do you ſeem to grieve
Thus, that in his life ſhewed ſuch contempt?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Oh brother, brother, ſeeking to deceive and blinde the world,
I have ruin'd and undone my ſelfe, the heavens
A • witneſſes, that Philanthus to me was more
Then father, you, and all the world. Then give me
Leave alone to grieve, ſince all griefes elſe are
but like drops to the vaſt Ocean.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Siſter, the Ocean hath his bounds, though large,
But my ſorrow, like to his love, for whom I grieve,
Muſt be beyond all limits, but his deſert,
The cauſe of my affliction.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Philanthus, Philanthus. But what are words, or fighes, or tears,
But weak expreſſions? let a dead ſilence rather ſhow,
They grieve not much, that can expreſſe their woe.

sp.p: Sir, your father.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Here, here.
Madam, the Duke.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Lov'd Philanthus, I know he did, and ſo did I,
Though I diſſembled, dearly I loved him; if there be charity
In you, open his tomb, that I may make his body know,
By kiſſing his pale lips, that I did love him,
More then he did me; his ſpirit's already
Satisfied, I know, elſe it would haunt me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You twins of ſorrow, that ſtrive with eagerneſſe,
Which ſhould be thought the trueſt mourner, make room
For one, whoſe actions have in point of love,
Outgone your airie words.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: I know that voice, Lucinda.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: For which of you, after the killing of a much lov'd brother,
For then I thought Adraſtus dead, became
Enamoured of his murderer, as I did of Philanthus?
Or which of you forſook your honours, or your ſtate,
Becomming like to me, a ſtragling Gipſie,
Forced to it, by a greater feeling of his merit,
Than ever touched your heart, purſuing him
In that diſguiſe, even when to hope the leaſt requitall
Had been madneſſe? and yet I muſt give proof
Beyond all theſe, when I have offered ſome
Few tears upon his Tombe.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Lucinda, for ſuch I know your name is, how would it vex me,
To hear you boaſt your love thus of Philanthus,
Were he alive; and yet I ſhould have gloried much,
To be by him preferred before ſo excellent a Lady
As your ſelfe: But ſince unkind brother,
But worſe friend, hath by his raſh hand, inrich'd
The Tombe, with what we both ſhould ſtrive for, let' joyne
In ſorrow, and from our moumfull eyes by turnes,
Drop tears, till by continuall motion, this hard
And unkinde Marble, may yield us paſſage to him,
Which it now denies.
And ſo at laſt we by our tears ſhall gain,
What now by prayers we cannot obtain.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: My dear children, why do you yield to ſorrow thus
Where there's no hope of remedy? I am a partner
In your griefe; you know that Philanthus was as
Dear to me as any; but ſince I know I cannot
Raiſe him to life by weeping, why ſhould I
Shew my ſelf a child, and mourn in vain?

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: How, my Siſter here, and mourning o're the Tomb
Of Philanthus, 'tis impoſſible, ſhe never ſaw him.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: You are deceived, Sir, be your own witneſſe.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: 'Tis ſhe. Degenerate from my blood, weep for mine
Enemy. Save you, Lady.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Brother, I know you wonder much to ſee me here;
But more, that I lament thus for a man,
Which you believe I knew not.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: I do, I ſee the great love that you profeſt to me,
Was wholly counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Rather your vertues, brother, are not what I thought'm •…
But love however's my excuſe.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Oh Philanthus!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ha! me-thought the ſpirit of Philanthus ſpoke from his Tomb.
Chiding my ſlackneſs in performing his will; did it not, Sir?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Not that I heard.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: His ghoſt appeared to me in dead of night,
And cruelly commanded me thus to preſent my ſelf
Before his Tomb, a gift unto the Prince Agenor,
From his dead friend.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: How! do you mock me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Which, though unwillingly, I here perform,
Much more to ſatisfie my promiſe to his ghoſt,
Than to requite your love; and yet, noble
Sorrow may be accounted merit.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Strange ghoſt!

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Madam, till now, my thoughts were in the grave with Philanthus,
His ſpirit it ſeemes, knowing my hearty ſorrow and repentance
Labour'd to make me happy in your love:
And I receive you with a joy above
What any tongue is able to expreſſe.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: This makes for my advantage, and is it poſſible,
Aurelia may return to love me, Philanthus
Being dead. Who's here, the Knight that fought with me?
Theſe Armes are ominous.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Come from the Tomb, Agenor, leave this ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Sir, I'le obey you for this time; but after, daily offer up
Tears of joy and ſorrow, in which Scene I ſtill
Muſt be an actor.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Aurelia, be not wilfull.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Thus all forſake me, no companions in my ſorrow left,
And I do glory in it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Sir, by your gratious favour: Lady, why weep you thus?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Ha! what are you ſo ignorant, that does not know the cauſe?

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.l: Do you know me then, the large expreſſion that
You made me of your reſpects, I might ſay love,
Made me believe, I ſhould not be ſo ſoon forgot.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Pardon me, Sir, I took you for this Knight then, for whom I now
Weep, whoſe body lies here in this Tomb, from whence
I do not mean to part; pray leave me, Sir. How got
This Knight theſe Armes, they are the ſame Philanthus wore.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Lady, you grieve for one, does not deſerve this ſorrow;
Behold in me a worthier ſervant, who now am come to claim
Performance of your ſo large promiſes. Point not to that,
I beat him whilſt he lived, and from him took theſe Armes.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Traitor Knight, thou lieſt; no, thou didſt rather
Play the thiefe, and ſteal them, which I will
Make thee confeſſe, elſe offer thee a
Sacrifice upon his Tombe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: In theſe Armes I overcame Adraſtus.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Thou lieſt, and ſhalt not live to injure thus
The dead; know, 'twas Philanthus by all the gods,
And this is.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Philanthus, your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Ha! is't poſſible.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Be not amazed, but truſt your eyes.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: How can this be?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You being wilfull and enraged, I rather
Ventured to receive one wound, and ſo ſeem ſlain,
Than in your death to loſe a friend, a Miſtreſſe,
And my own life too; but life would have bin hatefull
After your loſs, if I could have preſerv'd it.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: But mark his love, while his wounds yet bled;
(For to my charge, you know, you did commit
The body) He ſtudied to make you happy
In my Ladie's love, which was effected, by playing
His own ghoſt, whilſt I did in his Armes,
With you ſupply his place; how eaſie 'twas
To coſen you, and thoſe you ſent, by filling
The Coffin with ſome traſh, having my brother
To aſſiſt me in it, the dulleſt may conceive.
For my part, I was glad to raiſe my Miſtreſſe to a greater
At leaſt, if not a better fortune in
The Princes love.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Madam, I hope you will not make his labour fruitleſs.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It were in vain to croſs the will of heaven, which ſeemes
To have ordained Philanthus for your worthier ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: It lay not in my power till now, by reaſon of my wounds,
To keep my promiſe truly; but now, behold
Me ready to receive.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Me, as a recompence for all your ſufferings; no other puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Sir, we are joyn'd, and do mean to grow together,
If you do not ſevere us.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Enjoy your wiſhes both. Adraſtus,
For your ſiſters ſake I wiſh your friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Pardon the faults that grew from love to Aurelia,
And I ſhall ſtudy your advancement.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Brother, be better then you have been.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Which to begin, I give my ſelfe again
A ſervant to fair Miranthe, whoſe love, I know,
Not malice, croſs'd me in my love to Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I'le none, I thank you;
You that forſook me, aiming at a greater
Now offer'd I refuſe, hoping a better.

div.stage: Enter old Gudgen and young Gudgen.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Old man, I ſay to thee, be proud, and eke rejoyce, to ſee thy hopefull ſon ſalute the Duke in triumph, and by him reſaluted like to an Emperator.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Away rididulous aſſe.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Did not I tell you?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p:
Get you into the Country to your ſheep and
oxen, thoſe, you feed well, will like your company, here your Favouritſhip is growne ſtale; the Court is not ſo barren, but it brings forth daily ſome new humour, which at firſt is pleaſant, but after, like to yours, grows tedious.

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: Why, ſon, is this your gracing?

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: The envy of ſome Politick hath done this.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: See all things ſtraight prepared to ſolemnize
The happy marriages of theſe, in whom,
Friendſhip and love ſtrove for a name;
In you love, in you friendſhip overcame.

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: Come, ſon, come, after the loſs of all our mony, let's e'ne go home, and be wiſer once, never too old to learn.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: I, Father, but I am too young yet. Well, I will be a favourit for all this; I, ſo it ſhall be. Gentlemen, I mean to make a petition to the Duke, which I muſt intreat you to ſet your hand to, being the beſt judges of my ability; and thus it is:
sp.l: That ſince to be a worthy minion I'me not fit,
Yet I may be the chiefe fool-Favourit.
